# Coercion in Cyberspace – Taking Stock of the Debate

Mohamed S. Helal
Associate Professor of Law, The Ohio State University, Columbus, The United States of America; Member, Permanent Court of Arbitration; Member, African Union Commission on International Law (AUCIL); Special Rapporteur of the African Union on the Application of International Law in Cyberspace

## Abstract

This article explores debates among States on the application of the prohibition on intervention in cyberspace. It focuses on coercion as an element of the prohibition on intervention and identifies the different definitions of coercion that States have adopted in national and regional position papers on the application of international law in cyberspace. This article also specifically discusses the views of States on the threshold of coercion, which is the degree of harm or the effects that the conduct of a State must cause (or threaten to cause) to amount to a violation of the prohibition on intervention. This article argues that the definitions and thresholds of coercion that States have adopted in debates on the application of international law in cyberspace should be viewed as proposals for the development of the law in this area, as opposed to restatements of established law. Instead, this article proposes that all forms of intervention should be governed by a ‘unified threshold of coercion’ that applies to both forcible and non-forcible intervention.

## Keywords

prohibition on intervention – cyberspace – coercion – prohibition on the threat or use of force

# 1 Introduction

It is undisputed that the prohibition on intervention is a rule of customary international law.¹ This rule is also codified in numerous conventions, including the founding instruments of several regional organizations.² Non-intervention was also applied by the International Court of Justice (ICJ) in several cases,³ the most important of which is the Nicaragua Case.⁴ This rule was also reaffirmed in many UN General Assembly resolutions,⁵ the most notable of which is the 1970 Declaration on Principles of International Law Concerning Friendly Relations and Co-Operation Among States in Accordance with the Charter of the United Nations ('1970 Friendly Relations Declaration').⁶ The prohibition on intervention also appears in the 1949 Declaration on the Rights and Duties of States and the 1954 Code of Offenses Against the Peace and Security of Mankind which were adopted by the International Law Commission (ILC).⁷

COERCION IN CYBERSPACE - TAKING STOCK OF THE DEBATE

Invocations of the principle of non-intervention are also ubiquitous in diplomatic practice. States from every region and from every political bloc have accused their adversaries (and sometimes even their allies) of intervening in their affairs.[8]

In recent years, there has been a growing interest among States and scholars in the principle of non-intervention. One reason is that cyberspace has become a domain of conflict and competition. Information and communication technologies (ICTs) are being used both as weapons of war and as instruments of non-forcible intervention.[9] States, state-sponsored non-State actors, and non-State groups and individuals acting independently have employed ICTs against foreign States, citizens, and companies to achieve various political, economic, criminal, scientific, and financial objectives. ICTs have been used to disrupt critical infrastructure, spread disinformation and propaganda to sow social discord, interfere in elections, acquire industrial and trade secrets, steal scientific research and intellectual property, and to gain profit through activities such as ransomware attacks. As a result, there is a growing corpus of state practice and expressions of opinio juris, in addition to a sizable body of scholarship, on how the prohibition on intervention applies in cyberspace. This article engages with these discussions.

Specifically, this article has two objectives. First, it explores how States have defined the concept of coercion,[10] which is considered a core component of

This article will do so by surveying national and regional position papers that States have issued in recent years on the application of international law in cyberspace in which States have outlined their views on the scope and content of the prohibition on intervention and on how it governs the conduct of States in cyberspace. These position papers were issued, at least partially, in response to calls by the UN Open-Ended Working Group on Developments in the Field of Information and Telecommunications in the Context of International Security (OEWG) for States to express their opinions on how international law applies in cyberspace.¹² The OEWG is one of the two principal forums in which discussions at the UN on the regulation of cyberspace are conducted, the other being the UN Group of Governmental Experts on Advancing Responsible State Behaviour in Cyberspace in the Context of International Security (GGE).¹³

In addition to being of interest to scholars who specialize in the regulation of cyberspace, these national and regional position papers also deserve special attention from generalist scholars of international law. Most of these position papers are not framed as expressions of State views on *lex specialis* that apply only in cyberspace. Rather, they contain detailed statements on the scope and content of a wide range of *lex generalis* followed by discussions on how these rules of general international law apply in cyberspace. This makes these position papers a rich source of *opinio juris* on various primary and secondary rules

of international law, many of which are foundational to the international legal order. Some of the rules covered by these position papers include sovereignty, the prohibition on the threat or use of force, the peaceful settlement of disputes, human rights, the laws of armed conflict, the rules of attribution, and of course, the prohibition on intervention, which is the subject of this article.

Examining these national and regional position papers on the application of international law in cyberspace reveals that, while the prohibition on intervention is accepted as a rule of general international law, there remains considerable uncertainty regarding the exact scope and content of this rule. In particular, there are notable differences among States on the definition of coercion. Some States have defined coercion as conduct that modifies the behavior of a State by causing it to act involuntarily or by compelling it to act in a manner that it would not have voluntarily engaged in but for the coercive conduct of a foreign State. Other States have defined coercion as conduct that deprives a State of its freedom of choice or control over matters within its domestic jurisdiction. A third and broader approach, which was adopted by the African Union, defines coercion as any conduct that imposes restraints on the will of a foreign State.

In addition to articulating theoretical definitions of coercion, some States provided examples of conduct that, in their view, amounted to coercion. These examples shed further light on how the concept of coercion applies to real-world situations in which ICTs are used as instruments of statecraft. In particular, these examples clarify the views of States on the threshold of effects or the degree of pressure that a State must be subjected to in order for conduct to be considered coercive. As I show below, there is currently no consensus among States on the effects that the conduct of the coercing State must have on the coerced State to constitute an act of unlawful intervention. Some States adopted relatively high thresholds that require the conduct in question to have significant effects on the coerced State. For example, for some States, merely seeking to sway public opinion during an election campaign does not necessarily amount to unlawful intervention. Rather, to those States, electoral interference must rise to the level of altering election results or preventing a segment of the population from voting in order to constitute an act of intervention.[14] On the other hand, other States adopted lower thresholds to determine when

For example, one State noted that 'hack and leak' operations to influence public opinion could constitute a violation of the prohibition on intervention.¹⁵ The African Union also adopted a relatively low threshold of coercion that does not require the behavior of a foreign State to have significant effects on a State in order to amount to unlawful intervention.

In short, national and regional position papers on the application of international law in cyberspace indicate that there are divergences among States on how the prohibition on intervention governs state conduct in cyberspace. There is no agreement on a theoretical definition of coercion, there is no consensus on the threshold of effects that determines when specific state conduct that is designed to influence the behavior of other States constitutes coercion, and there is some uncertainty on how non-intervention relates to other rules such as the prohibition on the threat or use of force and the obligation to respect the territorial sovereignty of States.

Having catalogued the views that States have, heretofore, expressed on non-intervention and coercion in cyberspace, the second objective of this article is to critically appraise the understandings of coercion that States have adopted in their national and regional position papers. Specifically, this article makes the following two arguments.

First, this article contends that – as a matter of formal law – the positions expressed by States on the meaning of coercion should be viewed as proposals de lege ferenda, and not as restatements of established lex lata. This is because, as I explain below, nothing in the history of the development of the prohibition of intervention lends support to the definitions of coercion that States have espoused. Non-intervention first emerged in the early 20th century as a rule

of Inter-American conventional international law. Then, building on decades of advocacy principally by non-aligned States, the prohibition on intervention became a rule of general international law with the adoption of the 1970 Friendly Relations Declaration. However, at no point during the evolution of the prohibition on intervention did States define coercion as conduct that causes a State to behave involuntarily or that deprives a State of its freedom of choice or control over matters within its domestic jurisdiction. Indeed, the history of the development of this rule indicates that States never even conceived of coercion as the conceptual cornerstone of non-intervention.

Second, this article argues that the definitions of coercion adopted by some States are conceptually flawed. Echoing the ICJ's judgment in the Nicaragua Case,¹⁶ virtually all States agree that the prohibition on intervention proscribes coercion whether undertaken through armed force or through non-forcible means, such as economic or political instruments of statecraft. Many States also underscored that the use of armed force is the gravest form of intervention. Yet – paradoxically – applying the definitions of coercion espoused by many (especially Western) States would lead to a situation where the gravest form of intervention – armed force – is governed by a lower threshold than non-forcible forms of intervention that are considered less grave.

As discussed below, nothing in *jus ad bellum* requires an act that amounts to armed intervention to be of such gravity that it causes a State to behave involuntarily or deprives it of control over matters within its domestic jurisdiction, which are the definitions of coercion adopted by some States. Indeed, attacking a single military unit could constitute a violation of the prohibition on the threat or use of force and could even amount to an armed attack,¹⁷ regardless of its effect on the behavior of the target State. On the other hand, applying the definitions of coercion adopted by some States would require non-forcible forms of intervention to reach a level of gravity and intensity that causes (or threatens to cause) a State to act involuntarily or that deprives it of freedom of choice. As I explain below, these definitions entail an unreasonably high

Therefore, this article argues that States and scholars should consider adopting what I call the 'unified threshold of coercion' that applies to both forcible and non-forcible intervention. Based on this approach, non-forcible conduct would be considered coercive if its impact is comparable to the scale and effects of conduct that amounts to a violation of the threat or use of force. This unified threshold of coercion is lower than the thresholds of coercion that many States have adopted in their position papers on the application of international law in cyberspace.

This article consists of two sections. Section 1 provides a survey of the definitions of coercion that appear in national and regional position papers on the application of international law in cyberspace. This section also outlines the views of States on the interconnection between non-intervention and the prohibition on the use of force and the obligation to respect state sovereignty, which is a debate that sheds further light on the kinds of conduct that each of these rules applies to and regulates. Then in Section 2, this article critically appraises the understandings of coercion adopted by States and argues in favor of adopting what I call the 'unified threshold of coercion' that applies equally to both forcible and non-forcible forms of intervention.

## 2.1 Coercion as Conduct that Modifies the Behavior of a State

The first approach defines coercion as conduct that compels a State to modify its behavior. Among the States that adopted this approach, there were slight variations in the exact definition of coercion that those States formulated. Some States defined coercion as acts that aim to compel a State to act involuntarily. Estonia's position paper expressed this view. It stated:

When discussing if a cyber operation constitutes an unlawful intervention into the external or internal affairs of another state, the element of coercion is a key factor [...] Stemming from that, cyber operations that aim to force another nation to act in an involuntary manner or to refrain from acting in a certain manner, and target the other nation's domaine réservé (e.g., national democratic processes such as elections, or military, security or critical infrastructure systems) could constitute such an intervention.²³

Austria's national statement was similar to Estonia's. It stated: '[c]oercion occurs when a state seeks to compel another state to change its behaviour with respect to its internal or external affairs, i.e. to force that state to act in an involuntary manner or involuntarily refrain from acting in a particular way'.²⁴ Some States that adopted this understanding of coercion also included a 'but for' test in their definition of coercion. According to those States, an act would be coercive if it aimed at compelling a State to behave in a manner that it would not otherwise have engaged in voluntarily. Norway's position paper expressed this view:

A cyber operation must therefore not be carried out to compel the target State to take a course of action, whether by act or omission, in a way that it would not otherwise voluntarily have pursued (coercion) in matters relating to its internal or external affairs (domaine réservé).25

The Netherlands adopted a similar position. It defined coercion as an act 'compelling a state to take a course of action (whether an act or an omission) that it would not otherwise voluntarily pursue. The goal of the intervention must be to effect change in the behavior of the target state'.26 Denmark also defined coercion as an act that 'has a potential for compelling the target state to engage in an action that it would otherwise not take'.27 Switzerland and Poland also used similar terms. To Switzerland, coercion is conduct that 'seeks to cause another to act (or refrain from acting) in a way it would not otherwise',28 and Poland stated that coercion 'aims at influencing the state's decisions belonging to its domaine réservé', and added that cyberoperations 'potentially leading to the state's conduct that would not occur otherwise, may be considered a prohibited intervention'.29

Other States that understood coercion as conduct that is designed to modify the behavior of another State used relatively generic terms to define coercion. Romania, for example, defined coercion simply as an act the purpose of which is to 'effectively change the behavior of the target state'.30 Israel's Deputy Attorney General also opined that coercion 'has been taken to mean that State A cannot take actions to "coerce" State B in pursuing a course of action, or refraining from a course of action, in matters pertaining to State B's core internal affairs'.31 Singapore's national statement defined coercion in similar terms. It asserted that 'a State employs coercive means to compel another State to undertake or desist from a specific action, in matters falling under its domain réserve'.33 In other words, for these States, an act is coercive simply if it is intended to cause another State to change its behavior. These States did not, however, explicitly include a requirement that the conduct in question must compel a State to act involuntarily or force it to engage in behavior that it would not have engaged in voluntarily but-for the coercive conduct of a foreign State.

Germany adopted a generally similar understanding of coercion. Although it did not refer to modifying the behavior of a State or causing it to act involuntarily, Germany described coercion as the exercise of a certain level of pressure that has a significant impact on the decision-making process of a State to the extent that it manipulates or undermines the will of the State. Germany's position paper stated the following:

Generally, Germany is of the opinion that cyber measures may constitute a prohibited intervention under international law if they are comparable in scale and effects to coercion in non-cyber contexts.

Coercion implies that a State's internal processes regarding aspects pertaining to its domaine réservé are significantly influenced or thwarted and that its will is manifestly bent by the foreign State's conduct. However, as is widely accepted, the element of coercion must not be assumed prematurely. Even harsher forms of communication such as pointed commentary and sharp criticism as well as (persistent) attempts to obtain, through discussion, a certain reaction or the performance of a certain measure from another State do not as such qualify as coercion. Moreover, the acting State must intend to intervene in the internal affairs of the target State – otherwise the scope of the non-intervention principle would be unduly broad.34

As noted above in the introduction to this article, these examples provide greater clarity on how States operationalize and apply the definitions of coercion that they adopted. ## 2.3 Coercion as Conduct that Imposes Restraints on the Will of a State

The third approach to understanding coercion appears in the Common African Position on the Application of International Law to the Use of Information and Communication Technologies in Cyberspace, which was adopted by the fifty-five members of the African Union in early 2024.61 As of this writing, the African Union is the first regional organization to have adopted a position on the application of international law in cyberspace.62 The Common African Position defined coercion 'as a policy that is designed to impose restraints on the will of a foreign State. Assessing whether the use by one or more States of ICTs in cyberspace to influence the conduct of a foreign State amounts to coercion is a determination that should be undertaken on a case-by-case basis'.63 The Common African Position also stated the following:

While the definition of coercion in this context requires further study and deliberation between States, the African Union is of the view that it is not necessary, in order to constitute coercion, that the conduct of a State must rise to the level of completely depriving a foreign State of its freedom of choice or to compel that State to either act or refrain from acting involuntarily. Coercion may also occur through threats of intervention. Furthermore, there is no requirement that, in order to constitute a violation of the prohibition on intervention, an act of coercion must actually succeed in compelling the State subjected to such acts to change its conduct. An unsuccessful attempt of intervention is unlawful under international law. In some respects, the understanding of coercion in the Common African Position is similar to other definitions of coercion, but it also diverges from these definitions in significant ways. The Common African Position defined coercion as conduct that ‘impose[s] restraints on the will of a foreign State’. This is broadly analogous to the notion of impinging on the freedom of choice of States, which is central to the coercion-as-control model. However, the Common African Position also indicates that the purpose of intervention is to ‘influence the conduct of a foreign State’. This echoes definitions that understand coercion as conduct that aims at modifying the behavior of a State by subverting, manipulating, or undermining its decision-making processes.

Compared to other definitions of coercion, however, the Common African Position was purposively designed to broaden the protective scope of the prohibition on intervention. It does so by adopting a lower threshold of (actual or threatened) effects that must be crossed for conduct to amount to coercion. This is clearly expressed in the following sentence: ‘the African Union is of the view that it is not necessary, in order to constitute coercion, that the conduct of a State must rise to the level of completely depriving a foreign State of its freedom of choice or to compel that State to either act or refrain from acting involuntarily’.⁶⁵

In other words, the principal point of divergence between the Common African Position and the positions of other States relates to the threshold of coercion. For the member States of the African Union, intervention is any conduct undertaken by a State that imposes restraints on another State in relation to matters within its domestic jurisdiction. However, those restraints need not be of such severity that they cause a State to act involuntarily nor do they need to reach a level of intensity that completely deprives that State of its freedom of choice or control over matters within its domestic jurisdiction.

It is notable that, in an initial draft of the Common African Position that this author had prepared while serving as the African Union Special Rapporteur on the Application of International Law in Cyberspace, coercion was defined in the following terms: ‘coercion, in the context of the prohibition on intervention, should be defined as a policy that is designed to impose material restraints on the will of a foreign State’. ## 2.5 Sovereignty, Intervention, and the Use of Force: Demarcating the Doctrinal Boundaries

In addition to articulating definitions of coercion and offering examples of conduct that amounts to coercion, many States addressed the question of the relation between, on one hand, the prohibition on intervention and, on the other, the obligation to respect the territorial sovereignty of States and the prohibition on the threat or use of force. The content and scope of application of these three rules overlap significantly. As the ICJ observed in the Nicaragua Case, '[t]he effects of the principle of respect for territorial sovereignty inevitably overlap with those of the principles of the prohibition of the use of force and of non-intervention'.79

To disentangle the interconnection between these three rules, many States expressed views on the threshold of effects that must be crossed for conduct to amount to a violation of each of these rules. Surveying national and regional position papers on the application of international law in cyberspace reveals that States have approached this question from three different angles. The first relates to categories of conduct that – by their very nature – do not constitute a breach of the prohibition on intervention because they fall below the threshold of coercion. Nonetheless, some States noted that conduct that does not amount to intervention because it falls below the threshold of coercion may still be wrongful because it violates the principle of state sovereignty. The second is the higher threshold of coercion, which many States identified as the point at which non-intervention intersects with the prohibition on the threat or use of force. The third relates to the threshold at which non-forcible conduct – such as information operations, election interference, or economic sanctions – amount to coercion.

## 2.6 Conduct below the Threshold of Coercion

Many States identified certain forms of conduct that do not amount to unlawful intervention because they are considered non-coercive. Several Western States argued that practices designed to persuade a State to change its behavior or to influence its policies are lawful, even if such practices involve criticism of that State. ## 2.8 The Threshold of Non-forcible Coercion

This question of the exact threshold at which non-forcible conduct amounts to coercion is of critical importance. This is because most acts of unlawful intervention that could be undertaken through cyberspace are likely to fall below the threshold of forcible intervention. For example, activities such as election interference or disinformation campaigns will almost always fall below the threshold of the use of force.¹⁰⁸ In fact, this is precisely the area – conduct below the threshold of the use of force, but above the threshold of violations of territorial sovereignty – where the prohibition on intervention is most relevant.

National and regional position papers on the application of international law in cyberspace reveal that there is no consistency among States on the question of the threshold of coercion that applies to non-forcible intervention. This lack of consistency is evident even among States that adopted the same definition of coercion. In other words, even where there is some convergence among States on the meaning of coercion at a theoretical level, there are notable divergences on how the concept of coercion applies in real-world situations.

Among the States that defined coercion as conduct that modifies the behavior of a State or causes it to act involuntarily, there were notable differences in the terminology used to describe the threshold that applies to non-forcible coercion. Germany contended that, to constitute an act of intervention, a cyberoperation must be 'comparable in scale and effect to coercion in non-cyber contexts'. On the other hand, Poland indicated that, to constitute coercion, the foreign State's conduct must 'adversely affect' the 'functioning and security of the political, economic, military or social system of a state'.[111] Norway also provided examples of non-forcible coercive conduct that included 'manipulating election systems', 'unduly influencing public opinion', and 'causing a temporary shutdown' of critical infrastructure.[112]

## 3 Towards a Unified Threshold of Coercion

It is impossible, given the limitations of space, to comprehensively address the question of the threshold of coercion that applies to non-forcible conduct. This is a topic that requires further research. Nonetheless, in this section, this article will offer a general sketch of a threshold that could be employed to determine when non-forcible conduct amounts to coercion, thereby violating the prohibition on intervention. Specifically, this section proposes the adoption of a single, unified threshold of coercion that applies equally to both forcible and non-forcible intervention. According to this approach, non-forcible conduct would amount to coercion if its scale and effects are comparable to conduct that amounts to a violation of the prohibition on the threat or use of force.

Two considerations support this approach. The first is historical. Throughout its evolution, the prohibition on intervention was understood as a cognate of the prohibition on the threat or use of force.¹³⁴ Non-intervention was designed to extend the protections afforded to States under the prohibition on the threat or use of force to non-forcible – but no less pernicious – instruments of statecraft. The second consideration is conceptual. The definitions of coercion that appear in national position papers on the application of international law in cyberspace that some States have issued impose an unreasonably high threshold of effects that must be met for non-forcible conduct to amount to an act of intervention. Defining coercion as causing a State to act ‘involuntarily’ or ‘depriving’ it of freedom of choice requires causing effects or

However, because there is no agreement among States on the meaning of coercion, there is continued uncertainty regarding when non-forcible conduct amounts to unlawful intervention. The unified threshold of coercion addresses this question by proposing a single test that applies to all forms of intervention, including armed force, or the use of political, economic, or informational instruments of statecraft, or some combination thereof.

## 3.1 Coercion in the History of the Prohibition on Intervention

As argued in detail in another study by the present author, until the *Nicaragua Case* was decided by the ICJ in 1986, the concept of coercion was not defined, nor was it viewed as the cornerstone of the prohibition on intervention.¹³⁶ Moreover, throughout its evolution, States never understood intervention as conduct that causes a State to act involuntarily or that deprives it of its freedom of choice or control over its domestic jurisdiction. This is why, to this writer, the definitions of coercion that States have included in their national and regional position papers should be viewed as proposals *de lege ferenda*, and not restatements of established *lex lata*. This overview begins with three Inter-American treaties that first included non-intervention as a distinct rule of international law, followed by the 1970 Friendly Relations Declaration, the adoption of which marked the acceptance of the prohibition on intervention as a rule of general international law.

The prohibition on intervention originated as a rule of conventional international law in the Inter-American system. It was first codified in Article 8 of the 1933 Montevideo Convention on the Rights and Duties of States, which reads as follows: 'No State has the right to intervene in the internal or external affairs of another'.[137] The prohibition on intervention was further reaffirmed and its scope was expanded with the adoption of the 1936 Additional Protocol Relative to Non-Intervention, Article I of which states: 'The High Contracting Parties declare inadmissible the intervention of any one of them, directly or indirectly, and for whatever reason, in the internal or external affairs of any other of the Parties'.[138]

The principal purpose of these provisions was to overturn the right of States to resort to acts of intervention, which was established under 19th century international law. At the time, States were permitted wage war or to engage in so-called measures short of war – i.e., acts of intervention – for an expansive range of reasons.[139] These included preserving the balance of power, repelling attacks against a State's territory, preempting an imminent armed attack, obtaining reparation for injuries inflicted on the interests or honor of the State, protecting the lives and property of citizens, securing the repayment of debts, and preventing mass atrocities.[140] Intervention was accepted as permissible

Like its antecedents, the principal purpose of the first sentence of Article 19 was to reaffirm that, at least in Inter-American international law, the right of intervention that was recognized in 19th century international law was abolished. The inclusion of the phrase 'for whatever reason', which first appeared in the 1936 Non-Intervention Protocol, also indicated that non-intervention was an absolute rule that admitted no exceptions. Accordingly, the grounds that had previously been invoked to justify intervention – such as protecting citizens abroad, collecting debts, or enforcing international law – were no longer valid.

The second sentence of Article 19 clarified a principle that was only implicit in the 1933 Montevideo Convention and the 1936 Non-Intervention Protocol. It confirmed that non-intervention proscribed both the use of armed force and any other instrument of statecraft to engage in acts of intervention. Although, as noted above, the subcommittee that drafted the 1933 Montevideo Convention had affirmed that intervention could be undertaken 'through diplomatic representation, by armed force, or any other means involving effective force', this was not explicitly stated in either the 1933 Montevideo Convention or the 1936 Non-Intervention Protocol. The second sentence of Article 19 was also intended to prohibit acts of subversion that seek to impinge on the political independence of a State by subjugating it or transforming it into a satellite of a foreign power or that undermine its capacity to manage its political, economic, and cultural affairs autonomously.[152]

The negotiating history of the three Inter-American treaties in which the prohibition on intervention was first codified does not provide support for the definitions of coercion that many States have adopted in their national position papers on the application of international law in cyberspace. In fact, the concept of coercion was not even the subject of any in-depth discussions during the drafting of these treaties. Rather, the term coercion was only introduced in Article 20 of the OAS Charter specifically to outlaw the imposition of unilateral economic sanctions. Likewise, there is little in the negotiations on the principal instruments that were adopted on non-intervention by the UN that supports the definitions of coercion that appear in national position papers on the application of international law in cyberspace.

In short, the *travaux préparatoires* of the three Inter-American treaties and the two UN declarations in which non-intervention was codified provide no support for definitions of coercion that States have adopted in their position papers on how international law applies in cyberspace. Intervention was never understood as an act that causes a State to behave involuntarily or that deprives it of freedom of choice or control over matters within its domestic jurisdiction. That is why the definitions of coercion and the approaches of applying the prohibition on intervention that appear in these position papers should be viewed as proposals for the progressive development of international law in this area. In other words, these are proposals *de lege ferenda*.

## 3.2 Coercion as Conduct Comparable to the Use of Force

In addition to being unfounded in *lex lata*, defining coercion as acts that cause a State to behave involuntarily or that deprive a State of its freedom of choice or control over matters its domestic jurisdiction is conceptually flawed for two reasons. First, it would be incoherent to apply to non-forcible intervention that is undertaken through instruments such as information operations or economic sanctions a threshold of coercion that is higher than that which applies to the use of armed force, which is the gravest form of intervention. Second, even if one were to ignore the inconsistency between the thresholds of forcible and non-forcible intervention, the definitions of coercion that apply to the latter that some States have adopted are unreasonably high and severely restrict the scope of application of the prohibition on intervention. This section addresses these two points.

As noted above, virtually all position papers on the application of international law in cyberspace affirmed that the threat or use of force is *ipso facto* coercive. Many States also underscored that the use of force is the gravest form of coercion. This reflects the principle that the prohibition on the use of force is a peremptory rule of international law. Paradoxically, however, if, as many States propose, coercion is defined as conduct that causes a State to behave involuntarily or that deprives it of freedom of choice or control, non-forcible conduct would be governed by a higher threshold than that which applies to armed intervention. example of a prohibited intervention would be a malicious cyber activity that hacks and disables a State's election commission days before an election, preventing a significant number of citizens from voting, and ultimately influencing the election outcome.[179]

Under this definition, almost all of the conduct that appears in a recent report published by a commission established by the Canadian government to investigate foreign interference in Canadian elections would not be wrongful under the prohibition on intervention.[180] The report, which is titled Public Inquiry into Foreign Interference in Federal Electoral Processes and Democratic Institutions, noted that foreign interference did not determine the outcome of the election. The report did, however, state the following:

The fact that foreign interference may not have impacted the outcomes in many ridings does not mean, however, that it did not impact the election. Foreign interference in 2019 and 2021 undermined the right of voters to have an electoral ecosystem free from coercion or covert influence. Foreign interference has an impact when there is a single instance where a ballot is cast in a certain way, or not cast at all, because of a foreign state's direct or indirect enticement.[181]

The report added that this foreign interference affected the electoral ecosystem and had the overall effect of '[u]ndermining faith in democracy and government' and led to a 'reduced trust in Canada's democratic process'.[182] Under Canada's definition of coercion, this conduct would not be unlawful. The foreign interference catalogued in this report did not impose any particular choice on Canada nor did it significantly affect the outcome of an election. Likewise, this conduct would not meet the threshold of causing a State to act involuntarily. Nonetheless, the political effects of foreign interference of this nature are serious, especially in the long-term. Failing to proscribe conduct of this nature would turn the prohibition on intervention into a normative empty shell that provides little protection to States and would permit a broad range of disruptive non-forcible behavior.

HELAL

This is why I believe that the Common African Position was right to define coercion as conduct that is designed 'to impose restraints on the will of a foreign state', which is a markedly lower threshold than that proposed by other States. The question, however, is what exactly does 'imposing restraints' entail and at what point can one say that the exertion of pressure on a State has reached the point of 'imposing restraints' on its will?

To this writer – and I must emphasize that this is the author's view, not that of the member States of the African Union – the threshold of coercion for non-forcible conduct should be defined as being comparable to the minimum effects of conduct that amounts to a threat or use of force. In other words, for non-forcible conduct – such as political, economic, or informational measures – to amount to intervention, the effects of the conduct in question should be comparable to that which is entailed by the threat or use of force. I call this the unified threshold of coercion. The practical effect of adopting the unified threshold of coercion is that any non-forcible conduct that causes effects on a scale that is comparable to conduct that amounts to a violation of the prohibition on the threat or use of force would constitute a breach of the prohibition on intervention.

To further explain, other reports by the Canadian government provide understandings of foreign interference that, to this writer, approximates the degree of effects that would meet the unified threshold of coercion, thereby amounting to a breach of the prohibition on intervention. In one report published by the National Security and Intelligence Committee of Parliamentarians, foreign interference was defined in the following terms: '[f]oreign interference involves foreign states, or persons/entities operating on their behalf, attempting to covertly influence decisions, events or outcomes to better suit their strategic interests'.[183] This report also stated: 'foreign interference includes attempts to covertly influence, intimidate, manipulate, interfere, corrupt or discredit individuals, organizations and governments to further the interests of a foreign country'.[184] It also underscored that 'foreign interference should be understood as a long-term effort, akin to espionage, using inducements or threats. Both dynamics enable the manipulation of targets when required, for example, through requests for inappropriate or special favours'.[185] This report

184 Ibid.

185 Ibid., at 6.</https:>

provided examples of behavior that would not amount to unlawful intervention. These include:

Foreign interference activities are distinct from acceptable diplomatic advocacy and lobbying. The latter activities are known to the host state and occur through recognized channels to achieve specific policy outcomes or objectives. It is normal for foreign diplomats in Canada, for example, to reach out to elected officials across the political spectrum, to pressure policymakers, to use local media to promote their national interests or to engage with and support domestic organizations.^[186]^

An earlier report, also published by the National Security and Intelligence Committee of Parliamentarians of Canada, states the following: '[f]oreign interference activities can include using deceptive means to cultivate relationships with elected officials and others perceived to processes influence in the political process; seek to influence the reporting of Canadian media outlets; seek, in some cases, to affect the outcome of elections; and coerce or induce diaspora communities to advance foreign interests in Canada'.^[187]^ The understandings of foreign interference in these reports are palpably broader than the definition of coercion in most national position papers on the application of international law in cyberspace, including Canada's. To this writer, these reports describe the kinds of conduct that were intended to be covered by the Common African Position, and which would be covered by the unified threshold of coercion proposed here.

Two considerations lend support to this understanding of coercion. First, adopting a unified threshold of coercion that applies to both forcible and non-forcible intervention is consistent with the history of the evolution of the prohibition on intervention. Throughout the negotiations on instruments in which non-intervention was codified, States consistently viewed acts of intervention as being analogous to the use of force.^[188]^ For example, as noted above, the drafters of the 1933 Montevideo Convention described intervention

186 Ibid.
187 Government of Canada, 'National Security and Intelligence Committee of Parliamentarians: Annual Report 2019' (12 March 2020), available at <https: reports="" rp-2020-03-12-ar="" intro-en.html="" www.nsicop-cpsnr.ca=""> (accessed 11 August 2024), at 55.
188 I. Brownlie, 'The Use of Force in Self-Defense' (1961) 37 British Yearbook of International Law 183-268, at 187 ('The term [intervention] and the use made of it by Governments and writers have been a very considerable source of confusion. It is commonly used to describe any use or threat of force which is considered to be justifiable whether or not the intervention creates a state of war in the formal sense').</https:>

HELAL

as any act that amounts to 'effective force'. It indicates that the authors of the Montevideo Convention understood non-forcible intervention to be the functional equivalent of armed force.

Moreover, during the debates on the Montevideo Convention, several Latin American States underscored that non-intervention was closely associated to the prohibition on the use of force. For example, Argentina stated: 'What is intervention, then, but violence? [...] Intervention is violence.'[189] El Salvador also affirmed that '[b]ecause the American conscience is such that territorial acquisitions originated by violence cannot be recognized; that violence has generally come to disturb the life of our countries in the form of intervention'.[190] Peru also emphasized that 'war is proscribed, so is violence, but not the use of arms, the diplomatic measures or any other means of effective compulsion'.[191] Ecuador also highlighted that '[w]hat is intervention but a kind of war, disguised and wary' and argued that, having outlawed aggression pursuant to the 1933 Anti-War Treaty of Non-Aggression and Conciliation, it was only natural for the States of the western hemisphere to proscribe intervention.[192] Similarly, during the negotiations on the OAS Charter, Cuba called economic coercion 'treacherous, silent, and underhanded aggression'.[193]

Many States expressed similar views during the negotiations on both the 1965 Declaration on Non-Intervention and the 1970 Friendly Relations Declaration. For example, Guinea described intervention as a 'more pernicious' form of aggression,[194] Trinidad and Tobago called it 'subtle and insidious' aggression,[195] and the Congo argued that non-intervention covered 'political pressure, subversive activities, and other acts of aggression'.[196] Furthermore, throughout debates on non-intervention at the UN, many States frequently described non-intervention as being derivable from or a corollary of the non-use of force.[197] In short, in addition to outlawing intervention through armed

191 Ibid., at 123.
192 Ibid., at 113.
193 Novena Conferencia Internacional Americana, Actas y Documentos, Vol. I: Antecedentes – Secretaría General Reunión Preliminar – Sesiones Plenarias (Ministerio de Relaciones Exteriores de Colombia 1953), at 219.
194 UNGA, 'First Committee 1400th Meeting, Twentieth Session' (7 December 1965) UN Doc. A/C.1/SR.1400, at 275.
195 UNGA, 'First Committee, 1405th Meeting, Twentieth Session', at 316.
196 UNGA, 'First Committee 1400th Meeting, Twentieth Session', at 279.

force, the prohibition on intervention was designed to protect States against non-forceful conduct that was viewed as being functionally equivalent to the use of force – i.e., conduct that entailed a degree of pressure that is comparable to the use of armed force.

In addition to being consistent with the historical evolution of non-intervention, adopting a unified threshold of coercion that applies to all forms of intervention reflects the fact that non-intervention and the non-use of force share the same policy purpose. The ICJ has stated that ‘a rule of international law, whether customary or conventional, does not operate in a vacuum; it operates in relation to facts and in the context of a wider framework of legal rules of which it forms only a part’.¹⁹⁸ Writing in more colorful terms, James Crawford observed that ‘customary rules usually hunt in packs, connected by some familial relationship and interacting with each other’.¹⁹⁹

Non-intervention and the non-use of force belong to the same normative ‘pack’. These rules are part of what scholars call the ‘law of coexistence’, the policy purpose of which is to protect the autonomy of States and enable them to coexist peacefully in an anarchic international system.²⁰⁰ Specifically, these two rules – non-intervention and the non-use of force – are designed to protect the physical and functional manifestations of sovereignty. These two ‘domains’ of sovereignty – the physical and the functional – are expressed by the concepts of the ‘territorial integrity’ and ‘political independence’ of States, which appear in Article 2(4) of the UN Charter.²⁰¹ Non-intervention extended the

¹⁹⁸ Interpretation of the Agreement of 25 March 1951 Between the WHO and Egypt (Advisory Opinion) [20 December 1980] ICJ Rep. 73, at para. 10.

¹⁹⁹ J. Crawford, Chance, Order, Change: The Course of International Law, General Course on Public International Law (Brill Nijhoff 2014), at 56.

²⁰⁰ G. Abi-Saab, ‘Whither the International Community?’ (1998) 9 European Journal of International Law 248–265, at 254.

²⁰¹ ‘Political independence’ refers to ‘the autonomy in the affairs of the State with respect to its institutions, freedom of political decisions, policy making, and in matters pertaining to its domestic and foreign affairs’. See S. Blay, ‘Territorial Integrity and Political Independence’ in R. Wolfrum (ed.), Max Planck Encyclopedia of Public International Law (Oxford University Press 2010), available at <https: 10.1093="" display="" law="" law:epil="" opil.ouplaw.com="" 9780199231690="" 99231690-e1116=""> (accessed 17 July 2024), at para. 1. ‘Territorial integrity’ is not limited to prohibiting forceful changes to the boundaries of a State. It protects the physical space within which a State exercises political independence against outside intrusion or trespass. See C. Marxsen, ‘Territorial Integrity in International</https:>

HELAL

protection afforded to the territorial integrity and political independence of States against the threat or use of force to all other instruments of statecraft that could be employed to achieve the same objectives,²⁰² especially that such non-forcible intervention often has the potential to achieve greater harm to States than the threat or use of force.²⁰³

To be clear, the unified threshold of coercion proposed here should not be read as suggesting that non-intervention is coterminous with the prohibition on the threat or use of force. Far from it. Although both rules share the same policy purposes, the prohibition on intervention is broader than the prohibition on the threat or use of force. Non-intervention applies to any policy or practice, whether forcible and non-forcible, that impinges on the political independence or territorial integrity of States. In a sense, therefore, the prohibition on the threat or use of force should be viewed as a *lex specialis* that applies to a specific genus of intervention (namely, *armed* intervention). This body of *lex specialis* has been subsumed, *in toto*, within the broader *lex generalis* of the prohibition on intervention.

In conclusion, further research and further expressions of State views are needed on the definition and threshold of coercion. This is essential to understanding how the prohibition on intervention applies to and governs non-forcible conduct both in cyberspace and beyond. To this writer, however, the unified threshold of coercion that this article proposes provides a conceptual foundation on which to formulate a workable and conceptually coherent approach to applying the prohibition on intervention.

As Georges Abi-Saab wrote: 'The international legal system is based at present as in the past, on two fundamental principles that determine its structure and functioning, namely, the sovereignty and equality of States [...] The principal legal consequence of this structural or rather structuring principle is to commit each State to a general obligation to respect the sovereignty of others; in other words, not to trespass on the territorial and functional ambits of this sovereignty. The most flagrant manifestation of such trespass is the threat or use of force against the State. But it is not the only one. Other, less blatant, forms exist varying in their degree of visibility and intensity. It is precisely the rest of this continuum, beyond the use of force, which is covered by the principle of non-intervention'. G. Abi-Saab, 'Some Thoughts on the Principle of Non-Intervention' in K. # Coercion in Cyberspace – Taking Stock of the Debate
Mohamed S. Helal
Associate Professor of Law, The Ohio State University, Columbus, The United States of America; Member, Permanent Court of Arbitration; Member, African Union Commission on International Law (AUCIL); Special Rapporteur of the African Union on the Application of International Law in Cyberspace
## Abstract
This article explores debates among States on the application of the prohibition on intervention in cyberspace. It focuses on coercion as an element of the prohibition on intervention and identifies the different definitions of coercion that States have adopted in national and regional position papers on the application of international law in cyberspace. This article also specifically discusses the views of States on the threshold of coercion, which is the degree of harm or the effects that the conduct of a State must cause (or threaten to cause) to amount to a violation of the prohibition on intervention. This article argues that the definitions and thresholds of coercion that States have adopted in debates on the application of international law in cyberspace should be viewed as proposals for the development of the law in this area, as opposed to restatements of established law. Instead, this article proposes that all forms of intervention should be governed by a ‘unified threshold of coercion’ that applies to both forcible and non-forcible intervention.
## Keywords
prohibition on intervention – cyberspace – coercion – prohibition on the threat or use of force

# 1 Introduction
It is undisputed that the prohibition on intervention is a rule of customary international law.¹ This rule is also codified in numerous conventions, including the founding instruments of several regional organizations.² Non-intervention was also applied by the International Court of Justice (ICJ) in several cases,³ the most important of which is the Nicaragua Case.⁴ This rule was also reaffirmed in many UN General Assembly resolutions,⁵ the most notable of which is the 1970 Declaration on Principles of International Law Concerning Friendly Relations and Co-Operation Among States in Accordance with the Charter of the United Nations ('1970 Friendly Relations Declaration').⁶ The prohibition on intervention also appears in the 1949 Declaration on the Rights and Duties of States and the 1954 Code of Offenses Against the Peace and Security of Mankind which were adopted by the International Law Commission (ILC).⁷
1. R. Jennings and A. Watts, *Oppenheim’s International Law, Vol. I: Peace 428* (Oxford University Press 1992) ('That intervention is, as a rule, forbidden by international law there is no doubt. Its prohibition is a corollary of every state’s right to sovereignty, territorial integrity and political independence').
2. Examples of multilateral treaties in which non-intervention is codified include: Article 41(1) Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations (done 18 April 1961, entered into force 24 April 1964) 500 UNTS 95; Article 55(1) Vienna Convention on Consular Relations (done 23 April 1963, entered into force 19 March 1967) 596 UNTS 261. Some of the founding instruments of regional organizations in which the prohibition on intervention also appears, albeit in varying formulations, include: Articles 19–20 Charter of the Organization of American States (signed 30 April 1948, entered into force 13 December 1951) 119 UNTS 3; Article 4(g) Constitutive Act of the African Union (signed 11 July 2000, entered into force 26 May 2001) 2158 UNTS 3; Article 1(4) Charter of the Organization of Islamic Cooperation (adopted 14 March 2008), available at <https: charter="" en="" documents="" oic_charter_2018_en.pdf="" www.oic-oci.org="" upload="">; Article 2(2) Charter of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (done 20 November 2007, entered into force 15 December 2008) 2624 UNTS 223.

4. Case Concerning Military and Paramilitary Activities In and Against Nicaragua (Nicaragua v. United States of America) (Judgment) [1986] ICJ Rep. 14 ('Nicaragua v. USA'), at para. 205.
5. See for example UNGA Res. 31/91, 'Non-Interference in the Internal Affairs of States' (14 December 1976); UNGA Res. 36/103, 'Declaration on the Inadmissibility of Intervention and Interference in the Internal Affairs of States' (9 December 1981).
6. UNGA Res. 25/2625, 'Declaration on Principles of International Law Concerning Friendly Relations and Co-Operation Among States in Accordance with the Charter of the United Nations' (24 October 1970).
7. UNGA Res. 375 (IV), 'Draft Declaration on Rights and Duties of States' (6 December 1949); UN ILC, *Yearbook of the International Law Commission 1954, vol. II*, UN Doc. A/CN.4/SER.A/1954/Add.1, at 151.</https:>
COERCION IN CYBERSPACE - TAKING STOCK OF THE DEBATE
Invocations of the principle of non-intervention are also ubiquitous in diplomatic practice. States from every region and from every political bloc have accused their adversaries (and sometimes even their allies) of intervening in their affairs.[8]
In recent years, there has been a growing interest among States and scholars in the principle of non-intervention. One reason is that cyberspace has become a domain of conflict and competition. Information and communication technologies (ICTs) are being used both as weapons of war and as instruments of non-forcible intervention.[9] States, state-sponsored non-State actors, and non-State groups and individuals acting independently have employed ICTs against foreign States, citizens, and companies to achieve various political, economic, criminal, scientific, and financial objectives. ICTs have been used to disrupt critical infrastructure, spread disinformation and propaganda to sow social discord, interfere in elections, acquire industrial and trade secrets, steal scientific research and intellectual property, and to gain profit through activities such as ransomware attacks. As a result, there is a growing corpus of state practice and expressions of opinio juris, in addition to a sizable body of scholarship, on how the prohibition on intervention applies in cyberspace. This article engages with these discussions.
Specifically, this article has two objectives. First, it explores how States have defined the concept of coercion,[10] which is considered a core component of

10 Given the constraints of space and in the interest of brevity, I will not address every aspect of the scope and content of the prohibition on intervention. For instance, I will not delineate the exact areas of state policy that non-intervention protects, which have been variously referred to as 'internal and external affairs', 'internal affairs', 'domestic jurisdiction', and 'domain réservé'. Other issues that I will be unable to address here include the</https:></https:>

the prohibition on intervention.¹¹ It also examines how States have demarcated the boundary between, on one hand, the prohibition on intervention and, on the other, the obligation to respect the territorial sovereignty of States and the prohibition on the threat or use of force, which are two rules that are closely associated with the prohibition on intervention.
This article will do so by surveying national and regional position papers that States have issued in recent years on the application of international law in cyberspace in which States have outlined their views on the scope and content of the prohibition on intervention and on how it governs the conduct of States in cyberspace. These position papers were issued, at least partially, in response to calls by the UN Open-Ended Working Group on Developments in the Field of Information and Telecommunications in the Context of International Security (OEWG) for States to express their opinions on how international law applies in cyberspace.¹² The OEWG is one of the two principal forums in which discussions at the UN on the regulation of cyberspace are conducted, the other being the UN Group of Governmental Experts on Advancing Responsible State Behaviour in Cyberspace in the Context of International Security (GGE).¹³
In addition to being of interest to scholars who specialize in the regulation of cyberspace, these national and regional position papers also deserve special attention from generalist scholars of international law. Most of these position papers are not framed as expressions of State views on *lex specialis* that apply only in cyberspace. Rather, they contain detailed statements on the scope and content of a wide range of *lex generalis* followed by discussions on how these rules of general international law apply in cyberspace. This makes these position papers a rich source of *opinio juris* on various primary and secondary rules
¹¹ p. 11 A. Tzanakopoulos, ‘The Right to be Free from Economic Coercion’ (2015) 4 Cambridge Journal of International Law 616–633, at 620 (‘Coercion is a method of illegal intervention [...] coercion is intervention. Seeking to coerce a state within its sphere of freedom is wrongful; it constitutes intervention’).
¹² UNGA, ‘Open-Ended Working Group on Developments in the Field of Information and Telecommunications in the Context of International Security – Final Substantive Report’ (10 March 2021) UN Doc. A/AC.290/2021/CRP.2, at para. 38. (The OEWG recommended that ‘States, on a voluntary basis, continue to inform the Secretary-General of their national views and assessments on how international law applies to their use of ICTs in the context of international security, and continue to voluntarily share such national views and practices through other avenues as appropriate’).
¹³ See C. Painter, ‘The United Nations’ Cyberstability Processes: Surprising Progress but Much Left to Do’ (2021) 6 Journal of Cyber Policy 271–276.
COERCION IN CYBERSPACE - TAKING STOCK OF THE DEBATE
of international law, many of which are foundational to the international legal order. Some of the rules covered by these position papers include sovereignty, the prohibition on the threat or use of force, the peaceful settlement of disputes, human rights, the laws of armed conflict, the rules of attribution, and of course, the prohibition on intervention, which is the subject of this article.
Examining these national and regional position papers on the application of international law in cyberspace reveals that, while the prohibition on intervention is accepted as a rule of general international law, there remains considerable uncertainty regarding the exact scope and content of this rule. In particular, there are notable differences among States on the definition of coercion. Some States have defined coercion as conduct that modifies the behavior of a State by causing it to act involuntarily or by compelling it to act in a manner that it would not have voluntarily engaged in but for the coercive conduct of a foreign State. Other States have defined coercion as conduct that deprives a State of its freedom of choice or control over matters within its domestic jurisdiction. A third and broader approach, which was adopted by the African Union, defines coercion as any conduct that imposes restraints on the will of a foreign State.
In addition to articulating theoretical definitions of coercion, some States provided examples of conduct that, in their view, amounted to coercion. These examples shed further light on how the concept of coercion applies to real-world situations in which ICTs are used as instruments of statecraft. In particular, these examples clarify the views of States on the threshold of effects or the degree of pressure that a State must be subjected to in order for conduct to be considered coercive. As I show below, there is currently no consensus among States on the effects that the conduct of the coercing State must have on the coerced State to constitute an act of unlawful intervention. Some States adopted relatively high thresholds that require the conduct in question to have significant effects on the coerced State. For example, for some States, merely seeking to sway public opinion during an election campaign does not necessarily amount to unlawful intervention. Rather, to those States, electoral interference must rise to the level of altering election results or preventing a segment of the population from voting in order to constitute an act of intervention.[14] On the other hand, other States adopted lower thresholds to determine when
14 See for example P. Ney, ‘DOD General Counsel Remarks at US Cyber Command Legal Conference’ (2 March 2020) US Department of Defense, available at <https: 2099378="" article="" dod-general-counsel-remarks-at-us-cyber-command-legal-conference="" news="" speech="" www.defense.gov=""></https:> (Arguing that ‘a cyber operation by a State that interferes with another country’s ability to hold an election or that tampers with another country’s election results would be a clear violation of the rule of non-intervention’); Canadian Government, ‘International Law Applicable in Cyberspace’ (22 April 2022),
HELAL
electoral interference could be deemed coercive. For example, one State noted that 'hack and leak' operations to influence public opinion could constitute a violation of the prohibition on intervention.¹⁵ The African Union also adopted a relatively low threshold of coercion that does not require the behavior of a foreign State to have significant effects on a State in order to amount to unlawful intervention.
In short, national and regional position papers on the application of international law in cyberspace indicate that there are divergences among States on how the prohibition on intervention governs state conduct in cyberspace. There is no agreement on a theoretical definition of coercion, there is no consensus on the threshold of effects that determines when specific state conduct that is designed to influence the behavior of other States constitutes coercion, and there is some uncertainty on how non-intervention relates to other rules such as the prohibition on the threat or use of force and the obligation to respect the territorial sovereignty of States.
Having catalogued the views that States have, heretofore, expressed on non-intervention and coercion in cyberspace, the second objective of this article is to critically appraise the understandings of coercion that States have adopted in their national and regional position papers. Specifically, this article makes the following two arguments.
First, this article contends that – as a matter of formal law – the positions expressed by States on the meaning of coercion should be viewed as proposals de lege ferenda, and not as restatements of established lex lata. This is because, as I explain below, nothing in the history of the development of the prohibition of intervention lends support to the definitions of coercion that States have espoused. Non-intervention first emerged in the early 20th century as a rule
¹⁵ available at <https: issues_development-enjeux_developpement="" peace_security-paix_security="" eyberspace_law-cyberespace_droit.aspx?lang="eng" world-monde="" www.international.gc.ca=""> ('An example of a prohibited intervention would be a malicious cyber activity that hacks and disables a State's election commission days before an election, preventing a significant number of citizens from voting, and ultimately influencing the election outcome').
UNGA, 'Official Compendium of Voluntary National Contributions on the Subject of How International Law Applies to the Use of Information and Communications Technologies by States Submitted by Participating Governmental Experts in the Group of Governmental Experts on Advancing Responsible State Behavior in Cyberspace in the Context of International Security Established Pursuant to General Assembly Resolution 73/226' (13 July 2021) UN Doc. A/76/136 ('Official Compendium of Voluntary National Contributions'), at 69 (Norway: 'unduly influencing public opinion through the dissemination of confidential information obtained through cyber operations ("hack and leak"), would be in violation of the prohibition of intervention').</https:>
COERCION IN CYBERSPACE - TAKING STOCK OF THE DEBATE
of Inter-American conventional international law. Then, building on decades of advocacy principally by non-aligned States, the prohibition on intervention became a rule of general international law with the adoption of the 1970 Friendly Relations Declaration. However, at no point during the evolution of the prohibition on intervention did States define coercion as conduct that causes a State to behave involuntarily or that deprives a State of its freedom of choice or control over matters within its domestic jurisdiction. Indeed, the history of the development of this rule indicates that States never even conceived of coercion as the conceptual cornerstone of non-intervention.
Second, this article argues that the definitions of coercion adopted by some States are conceptually flawed. Echoing the ICJ's judgment in the Nicaragua Case,¹⁶ virtually all States agree that the prohibition on intervention proscribes coercion whether undertaken through armed force or through non-forcible means, such as economic or political instruments of statecraft. Many States also underscored that the use of armed force is the gravest form of intervention. Yet – paradoxically – applying the definitions of coercion espoused by many (especially Western) States would lead to a situation where the gravest form of intervention – armed force – is governed by a lower threshold than non-forcible forms of intervention that are considered less grave.
As discussed below, nothing in *jus ad bellum* requires an act that amounts to armed intervention to be of such gravity that it causes a State to behave involuntarily or deprives it of control over matters within its domestic jurisdiction, which are the definitions of coercion adopted by some States. Indeed, attacking a single military unit could constitute a violation of the prohibition on the threat or use of force and could even amount to an armed attack,¹⁷ regardless of its effect on the behavior of the target State. On the other hand, applying the definitions of coercion adopted by some States would require non-forcible forms of intervention to reach a level of gravity and intensity that causes (or threatens to cause) a State to act involuntarily or that deprives it of freedom of choice. Therefore, this article argues that States and scholars should consider adopting what I call the 'unified threshold of coercion' that applies to both forcible and non-forcible intervention. Based on this approach, non-forcible conduct would be considered coercive if its impact is comparable to the scale and effects of conduct that amounts to a violation of the threat or use of force. This unified threshold of coercion is lower than the thresholds of coercion that many States have adopted in their position papers on the application of international law in cyberspace.
This article consists of two sections. Section 1 provides a survey of the definitions of coercion that appear in national and regional position papers on the application of international law in cyberspace. This section also outlines the views of States on the interconnection between non-intervention and the prohibition on the use of force and the obligation to respect state sovereignty, which is a debate that sheds further light on the kinds of conduct that each of these rules applies to and regulates. Then in Section 2, this article critically appraises the understandings of coercion adopted by States and argues in favor of adopting what I call the 'unified threshold of coercion' that applies equally to both forcible and non-forcible forms of intervention.

## 2.1 Coercion as Conduct that Modifies the Behavior of a State
The first approach defines coercion as conduct that compels a State to modify its behavior. Among the States that adopted this approach, there were slight variations in the exact definition of coercion that those States formulated. Some States defined coercion as acts that aim to compel a State to act involuntarily. Estonia's position paper expressed this view. It stated:
When discussing if a cyber operation constitutes an unlawful intervention into the external or internal affairs of another state, the element of coercion is a key factor [...] Stemming from that, cyber operations that aim to force another nation to act in an involuntary manner or to refrain from acting in a certain manner, and target the other nation's domaine réservé (e.g., national democratic processes such as elections, or military, security or critical infrastructure systems) could constitute such an intervention.²³
Austria's national statement was similar to Estonia's. It stated: '[c]oercion occurs when a state seeks to compel another state to change its behaviour with respect to its internal or external affairs, i.e. to force that state to act in an involuntary manner or involuntarily refrain from acting in a particular way'.²⁴ Some States that adopted this understanding of coercion also included a 'but for' test in their definition of coercion. According to those States, an act would be coercive if it aimed at compelling a State to behave in a manner that it would not otherwise have engaged in voluntarily. ## 2.2 Coercion as Conduct that Deprives a State of Freedom of Choice or Control

## 2.3 Coercion as Conduct that Imposes Restraints on the Will of a State
The third approach to understanding coercion appears in the Common African Position on the Application of International Law to the Use of Information and Communication Technologies in Cyberspace, which was adopted by the fifty-five members of the African Union in early 2024.61 As of this writing, the African Union is the first regional organization to have adopted a position on the application of international law in cyberspace.62 The Common African Position defined coercion 'as a policy that is designed to impose restraints on the will of a foreign State. Assessing whether the use by one or more States of ICTs in cyberspace to influence the conduct of a foreign State amounts to coercion is a determination that should be undertaken on a case-by-case basis'.63 The Common African Position also stated the following:
While the definition of coercion in this context requires further study and deliberation between States, the African Union is of the view that it is not necessary, in order to constitute coercion, that the conduct of a State must rise to the level of completely depriving a foreign State of its freedom of choice or to compel that State to either act or refrain from acting involuntarily. Coercion may also occur through threats of intervention. Furthermore, there is no requirement that, in order to constitute a violation of the prohibition on intervention, an act of coercion must actually succeed in compelling the State subjected to such acts to change its conduct. An unsuccessful attempt of intervention is unlawful under international law. In some respects, the understanding of coercion in the Common African Position is similar to other definitions of coercion, but it also diverges from these definitions in significant ways. The Common African Position defined coercion as conduct that ‘impose[s] restraints on the will of a foreign State’. This is broadly analogous to the notion of impinging on the freedom of choice of States, which is central to the coercion-as-control model. However, the Common African Position also indicates that the purpose of intervention is to ‘influence the conduct of a foreign State’. This echoes definitions that understand coercion as conduct that aims at modifying the behavior of a State by subverting, manipulating, or undermining its decision-making processes.
Compared to other definitions of coercion, however, the Common African Position was purposively designed to broaden the protective scope of the prohibition on intervention. It does so by adopting a lower threshold of (actual or threatened) effects that must be crossed for conduct to amount to coercion. This is clearly expressed in the following sentence: ‘the African Union is of the view that it is not necessary, in order to constitute coercion, that the conduct of a State must rise to the level of completely depriving a foreign State of its freedom of choice or to compel that State to either act or refrain from acting involuntarily’.⁶⁵
In other words, the principal point of divergence between the Common African Position and the positions of other States relates to the threshold of coercion. For the member States of the African Union, intervention is any conduct undertaken by a State that imposes restraints on another State in relation to matters within its domestic jurisdiction. However, those restraints need not be of such severity that they cause a State to act involuntarily nor do they need to reach a level of intensity that completely deprives that State of its freedom of choice or control over matters within its domestic jurisdiction.
It is notable that, in an initial draft of the Common African Position that this author had prepared while serving as the African Union Special Rapporteur on the Application of International Law in Cyberspace, coercion was defined in the following terms: ‘coercion, in the context of the prohibition on intervention, should be defined as a policy that is designed to impose material restraints on the will of a foreign State’.
