In addition to being consistent with the historical evolution of non-intervention, adopting a unified threshold of coercion that applies to all forms of intervention reflects the fact that non-intervention and the non-use of force share the same policy purpose. The ICJ has stated that ‘a rule of international law, whether customary or conventional, does not operate in a vacuum; it operates in relation to facts and in the context of a wider framework of legal rules of which it forms only a part’. Writing in more colorful terms, James Crawford observed that ‘customary rules usually hunt in packs, connected by some familial relationship and interacting with each other’.
Non-intervention and the non-use of force belong to the same normative ‘pack’. These rules are part of what scholars call the ‘law of coexistence’, the policy purpose of which is to protect the autonomy of States and enable them to coexist peacefully in an anarchic international system. Specifically, these two rules – non-intervention and the non-use of force – are designed to protect the physical and functional manifestations of sovereignty. These two ‘domains’ of sovereignty – the physical and the functional – are expressed by the concepts of the ‘territorial integrity’ and ‘political independence’ of States, which appear in Article 2(4) of the UN Charter. To be clear, the unified threshold of coercion proposed here should not be read as suggesting that non-intervention is coterminous with the prohibition on the threat or use of force. Far from it. Although both rules share the same policy purposes, the prohibition on intervention is broader than the prohibition on the threat or use of force. Non-intervention applies to any policy or practice, whether forcible and non-forcible, that impinges on the political independence or territorial integrity of States. In a sense, therefore, the prohibition on the threat or use of force should be viewed as a *lex specialis* that applies to a specific genus of intervention (namely, *armed* intervention). This body of *lex specialis* has been subsumed, *in toto*, within the broader *lex generalis* of the prohibition on intervention.
In conclusion, further research and further expressions of State views are needed on the definition and threshold of coercion. This is essential to understanding how the prohibition on intervention applies to and governs non-forcible conduct both in cyberspace and beyond. # Coercion in Cyberspace – Taking Stock of the Debate
Mohamed S. Helal
Associate Professor of Law, The Ohio State University, Columbus, The United States of America; Member, Permanent Court of Arbitration; Member, African Union Commission on International Law (AUCIL); Special Rapporteur of the African Union on the Application of International Law in Cyberspace
## Abstract
This article explores debates among States on the application of the prohibition on intervention in cyberspace. It focuses on coercion as an element of the prohibition on intervention and identifies the different definitions of coercion that States have adopted in national and regional position papers on the application of international law in cyberspace. This article also specifically discusses the views of States on the threshold of coercion, which is the degree of harm or the effects that the conduct of a State must cause (or threaten to cause) to amount to a violation of the prohibition on intervention. This article argues that the definitions and thresholds of coercion that States have adopted in debates on the application of international law in cyberspace should be viewed as proposals for the development of the law in this area, as opposed to restatements of established law. Instead, this article proposes that all forms of intervention should be governed by a ‘unified threshold of coercion’ that applies to both forcible and non-forcible intervention.
## Keywords
prohibition on intervention – cyberspace – coercion – prohibition on the threat or use of force

# 1 Introduction
It is undisputed that the prohibition on intervention is a rule of customary international law.¹ This rule is also codified in numerous conventions, including the founding instruments of several regional organizations.² Non-intervention was also applied by the International Court of Justice (ICJ) in several cases,³ the most important of which is the Nicaragua Case.⁴ This rule was also reaffirmed in many UN General Assembly resolutions,⁵ the most notable of which is the 1970 Declaration on Principles of International Law Concerning Friendly Relations and Co-Operation Among States in Accordance with the Charter of the United Nations ('1970 Friendly Relations Declaration').⁶ The prohibition on intervention also appears in the 1949 Declaration on the Rights and Duties of States and the 1954 Code of Offenses Against the Peace and Security of Mankind which were adopted by the International Law Commission (ILC).⁷

Its prohibition is a corollary of every state’s right to sovereignty, territorial integrity and political independence').
2. Some of the founding instruments of regional organizations in which the prohibition on intervention also appears, albeit in varying formulations, include: Articles 19–20 Charter of the Organization of American States (signed 30 April 1948, entered into force 13 December 1951) 119 UNTS 3; Article 4(g) Constitutive Act of the African Union (signed 11 July 2000, entered into force 26 May 2001) 2158 UNTS 3; Article 1(4) Charter of the Organization of Islamic Cooperation (adopted 14 March 2008), available at <https: charter="" en="" documents="" oic_charter_2018_en.pdf="" www.oic-oci.org="" upload="">; Article 2(2) Charter of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (done 20 November 2007, entered into force 15 December 2008) 2624 UNTS 223.

Invocations of the principle of non-intervention are also ubiquitous in diplomatic practice. States from every region and from every political bloc have accused their adversaries (and sometimes even their allies) of intervening in their affairs.
In recent years, there has been a growing interest among States and scholars in the principle of non-intervention. One reason is that cyberspace has become a domain of conflict and competition. Information and communication technologies (ICTs) are being used both as weapons of war and as instruments of non-forcible intervention. States, state-sponsored non-State actors, and non-State groups and individuals acting independently have employed ICTs against foreign States, citizens, and companies to achieve various political, economic, criminal, scientific, and financial objectives. ICTs have been used to disrupt critical infrastructure, spread disinformation and propaganda to sow social discord, interfere in elections, acquire industrial and trade secrets, steal scientific research and intellectual property, and to gain profit through activities such as ransomware attacks. As a result, there is a growing corpus of state practice and expressions of opinio juris, in addition to a sizable body of scholarship, on how the prohibition on intervention applies in cyberspace. This article engages with these discussions.
Specifically, this article has two objectives. First, it explores how States have defined the concept of coercion, which is considered a core component of

the prohibition on intervention.¹¹ It also examines how States have demarcated the boundary between, on one hand, the prohibition on intervention and, on the other, the obligation to respect the territorial sovereignty of States and the prohibition on the threat or use of force, which are two rules that are closely associated with the prohibition on intervention.
This article will do so by surveying national and regional position papers that States have issued in recent years on the application of international law in cyberspace in which States have outlined their views on the scope and content of the prohibition on intervention and on how it governs the conduct of States in cyberspace. These position papers were issued, at least partially, in response to calls by the UN Open-Ended Working Group on Developments in the Field of Information and Telecommunications in the Context of International Security (OEWG) for States to express their opinions on how international law applies in cyberspace.¹² The OEWG is one of the two principal forums in which discussions at the UN on the regulation of cyberspace are conducted, the other being the UN Group of Governmental Experts on Advancing Responsible State Behaviour in Cyberspace in the Context of International Security (GGE).¹³
In addition to being of interest to scholars who specialize in the regulation of cyberspace, these national and regional position papers also deserve special attention from generalist scholars of international law. Most of these position papers are not framed as expressions of State views on *lex specialis* that apply only in cyberspace. Rather, they contain detailed statements on the scope and content of a wide range of *lex generalis* followed by discussions on how these rules of general international law apply in cyberspace. This makes these position papers a rich source of *opinio juris* on various primary and secondary rules

Tzanakopoulos, ‘The Right to be Free from Economic Coercion’ (2015) 4 Cambridge Journal of International Law 616–633, at 620 (‘Coercion is a method of illegal intervention [...] coercion is intervention. Seeking to coerce a state within its sphere of freedom is wrongful; it constitutes intervention’).
¹² UNGA, ‘Open-Ended Working Group on Developments in the Field of Information and Telecommunications in the Context of International Security – Final Substantive Report’ (10 March 2021) UN Doc. A/AC.290/2021/CRP.2, at para. 38. (The OEWG recommended that ‘States, on a voluntary basis, continue to inform the Secretary-General of their national views and assessments on how international law applies to their use of ICTs in the context of international security, and continue to voluntarily share such national views and practices through other avenues as appropriate’).
¹³ See C. Painter, ‘The United Nations’ Cyberstability Processes: Surprising Progress but Much Left to Do’ (2021) 6 Journal of Cyber Policy 271–276.

of international law, many of which are foundational to the international legal order. Some of the rules covered by these position papers include sovereignty, the prohibition on the threat or use of force, the peaceful settlement of disputes, human rights, the laws of armed conflict, the rules of attribution, and of course, the prohibition on intervention, which is the subject of this article.
Examining these national and regional position papers on the application of international law in cyberspace reveals that, while the prohibition on intervention is accepted as a rule of general international law, there remains considerable uncertainty regarding the exact scope and content of this rule. In particular, there are notable differences among States on the definition of coercion. Some States have defined coercion as conduct that modifies the behavior of a State by causing it to act involuntarily or by compelling it to act in a manner that it would not have voluntarily engaged in but for the coercive conduct of a foreign State. Other States have defined coercion as conduct that deprives a State of its freedom of choice or control over matters within its domestic jurisdiction. A third and broader approach, which was adopted by the African Union, defines coercion as any conduct that imposes restraints on the will of a foreign State.
In addition to articulating theoretical definitions of coercion, some States provided examples of conduct that, in their view, amounted to coercion. These examples shed further light on how the concept of coercion applies to real-world situations in which ICTs are used as instruments of statecraft. In particular, these examples clarify the views of States on the threshold of effects or the degree of pressure that a State must be subjected to in order for conduct to be considered coercive. As I show below, there is currently no consensus among States on the effects that the conduct of the coercing State must have on the coerced State to constitute an act of unlawful intervention. Some States adopted relatively high thresholds that require the conduct in question to have significant effects on the coerced State. For example, for some States, merely seeking to sway public opinion during an election campaign does not necessarily amount to unlawful intervention. Rather, to those States, electoral interference must rise to the level of altering election results or preventing a segment of the population from voting in order to constitute an act of intervention. On the other hand, other States adopted lower thresholds to determine when

electoral interference could be deemed coercive. For example, one State noted that 'hack and leak' operations to influence public opinion could constitute a violation of the prohibition on intervention.¹⁵ The African Union also adopted a relatively low threshold of coercion that does not require the behavior of a foreign State to have significant effects on a State in order to amount to unlawful intervention.
In short, national and regional position papers on the application of international law in cyberspace indicate that there are divergences among States on how the prohibition on intervention governs state conduct in cyberspace. There is no agreement on a theoretical definition of coercion, there is no consensus on the threshold of effects that determines when specific state conduct that is designed to influence the behavior of other States constitutes coercion, and there is some uncertainty on how non-intervention relates to other rules such as the prohibition on the threat or use of force and the obligation to respect the territorial sovereignty of States.
Having catalogued the views that States have, heretofore, expressed on non-intervention and coercion in cyberspace, the second objective of this article is to critically appraise the understandings of coercion that States have adopted in their national and regional position papers. Specifically, this article makes the following two arguments.
First, this article contends that – as a matter of formal law – the positions expressed by States on the meaning of coercion should be viewed as proposals de lege ferenda, and not as restatements of established lex lata. This is because, as I explain below, nothing in the history of the development of the prohibition of intervention lends support to the definitions of coercion that States have espoused. Non-intervention first emerged in the early 20th century as a rule

A/76/136 ('Official Compendium of Voluntary National Contributions'), at 69 (Norway: 'unduly influencing public opinion through the dissemination of confidential information obtained through cyber operations ("hack and leak"), would be in violation of the prohibition of intervention').</https:>

of Inter-American conventional international law. Then, building on decades of advocacy principally by non-aligned States, the prohibition on intervention became a rule of general international law with the adoption of the 1970 Friendly Relations Declaration. However, at no point during the evolution of the prohibition on intervention did States define coercion as conduct that causes a State to behave involuntarily or that deprives a State of its freedom of choice or control over matters within its domestic jurisdiction. Indeed, the history of the development of this rule indicates that States never even conceived of coercion as the conceptual cornerstone of non-intervention.
Second, this article argues that the definitions of coercion adopted by some States are conceptually flawed. Echoing the ICJ's judgment in the Nicaragua Case,¹⁶ virtually all States agree that the prohibition on intervention proscribes coercion whether undertaken through armed force or through non-forcible means, such as economic or political instruments of statecraft. Many States also underscored that the use of armed force is the gravest form of intervention. Yet – paradoxically – applying the definitions of coercion espoused by many (especially Western) States would lead to a situation where the gravest form of intervention – armed force – is governed by a lower threshold than non-forcible forms of intervention that are considered less grave.
As discussed below, nothing in *jus ad bellum* requires an act that amounts to armed intervention to be of such gravity that it causes a State to behave involuntarily or deprives it of control over matters within its domestic jurisdiction, which are the definitions of coercion adopted by some States. Indeed, attacking a single military unit could constitute a violation of the prohibition on the threat or use of force and could even amount to an armed attack,¹⁷ regardless of its effect on the behavior of the target State. On the other hand, applying the definitions of coercion adopted by some States would require non-forcible forms of intervention to reach a level of gravity and intensity that causes (or threatens to cause) a State to act involuntarily or that deprives it of freedom of choice. As I explain below, these definitions entail an unreasonably high

threshold of effects for non-forcible intervention that is significantly higher than that which applies to forcible intervention.
Therefore, this article argues that States and scholars should consider adopting what I call the 'unified threshold of coercion' that applies to both forcible and non-forcible intervention. Based on this approach, non-forcible conduct would be considered coercive if its impact is comparable to the scale and effects of conduct that amounts to a violation of the threat or use of force. This unified threshold of coercion is lower than the thresholds of coercion that many States have adopted in their position papers on the application of international law in cyberspace.
This article consists of two sections. Section 1 provides a survey of the definitions of coercion that appear in national and regional position papers on the application of international law in cyberspace. This section also outlines the views of States on the interconnection between non-intervention and the prohibition on the use of force and the obligation to respect state sovereignty, which is a debate that sheds further light on the kinds of conduct that each of these rules applies to and regulates. Then in Section 2, this article critically appraises the understandings of coercion adopted by States and argues in favor of adopting what I call the 'unified threshold of coercion' that applies equally to both forcible and non-forcible forms of intervention.

## 2.1 Coercion as Conduct that Modifies the Behavior of a State
The first approach defines coercion as conduct that compels a State to modify its behavior. Among the States that adopted this approach, there were slight variations in the exact definition of coercion that those States formulated. According to those States, an act would be coercive if it aimed at compelling a State to behave in a manner that it would not otherwise have engaged in voluntarily. ## 2.2 Coercion as Conduct that Deprives a State of Freedom of Choice or Control
The second understanding of coercion that has emerged out of national position papers on the application of international law in cyberspace defines coercion as an act that deprives a State of its ability to control or to exercise freedom of choice regarding matters within its domaine réservé. ## 2.3 Coercion as Conduct that Imposes Restraints on the Will of a State
The third approach to understanding coercion appears in the Common African Position on the Application of International Law to the Use of Information and Communication Technologies in Cyberspace, which was adopted by the fifty-five members of the African Union in early 2024.61 As of this writing, the African Union is the first regional organization to have adopted a position on the application of international law in cyberspace.62 The Common African Position defined coercion 'as a policy that is designed to impose restraints on the will of a foreign State. Assessing whether the use by one or more States of ICTs in cyberspace to influence the conduct of a foreign State amounts to coercion is a determination that should be undertaken on a case-by-case basis'.63 The Common African Position also stated the following:
While the definition of coercion in this context requires further study and deliberation between States, the African Union is of the view that it is not necessary, in order to constitute coercion, that the conduct of a State must rise to the level of completely depriving a foreign State of its freedom of choice or to compel that State to either act or refrain from acting involuntarily. Coercion may also occur through threats of intervention. Furthermore, there is no requirement that, in order to constitute a violation of the prohibition on intervention, an act of coercion must actually succeed in compelling the State subjected to such acts to change its conduct. An unsuccessful attempt of intervention is unlawful under international law. The African Union stresses that offers or calls to peacefully settle disputes through negotiation, enquiry, mediation, conciliation, good offices, arbitration, and judicial settlement, and diplomatic

In some respects, the understanding of coercion in the Common African Position is similar to other definitions of coercion, but it also diverges from these definitions in significant ways. The Common African Position defined coercion as conduct that ‘impose[s] restraints on the will of a foreign State’. This is broadly analogous to the notion of impinging on the freedom of choice of States, which is central to the coercion-as-control model. However, the Common African Position also indicates that the purpose of intervention is to ‘influence the conduct of a foreign State’. This echoes definitions that understand coercion as conduct that aims at modifying the behavior of a State by subverting, manipulating, or undermining its decision-making processes.
Compared to other definitions of coercion, however, the Common African Position was purposively designed to broaden the protective scope of the prohibition on intervention. It does so by adopting a lower threshold of (actual or threatened) effects that must be crossed for conduct to amount to coercion. This is clearly expressed in the following sentence: ‘the African Union is of the view that it is not necessary, in order to constitute coercion, that the conduct of a State must rise to the level of completely depriving a foreign State of its freedom of choice or to compel that State to either act or refrain from acting involuntarily’.⁶⁵
In other words, the principal point of divergence between the Common African Position and the positions of other States relates to the threshold of coercion. For the member States of the African Union, intervention is any conduct undertaken by a State that imposes restraints on another State in relation to matters within its domestic jurisdiction. However, those restraints need not be of such severity that they cause a State to act involuntarily nor do they need to reach a level of intensity that completely deprives that State of its freedom of choice or control over matters within its domestic jurisdiction.
It is notable that, in an initial draft of the Common African Position that this author had prepared while serving as the African Union Special Rapporteur on the Application of International Law in Cyberspace, coercion was defined in the following terms: ‘coercion, in the context of the prohibition on intervention, should be defined as a policy that is designed to impose material restraints on the will of a foreign State’. For instance, Norway stated that holding elections is an example of an activity that falls within the *domaine réservé* of a State. Therefore, according to Norway, 'carrying out cyber operations with the intent of altering election results in another State' would violate the prohibition on intervention. Furthermore, Canada, Denmark, and the US, understood coercion as conduct that is *designed* to achieve a specific purpose or effect (such as modifying the behavior of the target State). As noted above, the Common African Position also understood coercion as conduct that is *'designed* to impose restraints on the will of a foreign State'. The use of the term *'designed'* by these position papers introduces the element of intent into the definition of coercion. It indicates that the coercing State is acting purposefully and intentionally and employing its resources in a systematic and strategic manner to achieve specific policy objectives.

## 2.5 Sovereignty, Intervention, and the Use of Force: Demarcating the Doctrinal Boundaries
In addition to articulating definitions of coercion and offering examples of conduct that amounts to coercion, many States addressed the question of the relation between, on one hand, the prohibition on intervention and, on the other, the obligation to respect the territorial sovereignty of States and the prohibition on the threat or use of force. The content and scope of application of these three rules overlap significantly. As the ICJ observed in the Nicaragua Case, '[t]he effects of the principle of respect for territorial sovereignty inevitably overlap with those of the principles of the prohibition of the use of force and of non-intervention'.79
To disentangle the interconnection between these three rules, many States expressed views on the threshold of effects that must be crossed for conduct to amount to a violation of each of these rules. Surveying national and regional position papers on the application of international law in cyberspace reveals that States have approached this question from three different angles. The first relates to categories of conduct that – by their very nature – do not constitute a breach of the prohibition on intervention because they fall below the threshold of coercion. Nonetheless, some States noted that conduct that does not amount to intervention because it falls below the threshold of coercion may still be wrongful because it violates the principle of state sovereignty. The second is the higher threshold of coercion, which many States identified as the point at which non-intervention intersects with the prohibition on the threat or use of force. The third relates to the threshold at which non-forcible conduct – such as information operations, election interference, or economic sanctions – amount to coercion.

## 2.6 Conduct below the Threshold of Coercion
Many States identified certain forms of conduct that do not amount to unlawful intervention because they are considered non-coercive. Several Western States argued that practices designed to persuade a State to change its behavior or to influence its policies are lawful, even if such practices involve criticism of that State. These Western States argued that such conduct is commonplace in international relations, which means that it should not be condemned as a form of intervention.⁸⁰ This was a point of convergence among Western States regardless of the definitions of coercion they adopted.

## 2.8 The Threshold of Non-forcible Coercion
This question of the exact threshold at which non-forcible conduct amounts to coercion is of critical importance. This is because most acts of unlawful intervention that could be undertaken through cyberspace are likely to fall below the threshold of forcible intervention. For example, activities such as election interference or disinformation campaigns will almost always fall below the threshold of the use of force.¹⁰⁸ In fact, this is precisely the area – conduct below the threshold of the use of force, but above the threshold of violations of territorial sovereignty – where the prohibition on intervention is most relevant.

National and regional position papers on the application of international law in cyberspace reveal that there is no consistency among States on the question of the threshold of coercion that applies to non-forcible intervention. This lack of consistency is evident even among States that adopted the same definition of coercion. In other words, even where there is some convergence among States on the meaning of coercion at a theoretical level, there are notable divergences on how the concept of coercion applies in real-world situations.
Among the States that defined coercion as conduct that modifies the behavior of a State or causes it to act involuntarily, there were notable differences in the terminology used to describe the threshold that applies to non-forcible coercion. Germany contended that, to constitute an act of intervention, a cyberoperation must be 'comparable in scale and effect to coercion in non-cyber contexts'. According to Germany, to meet the threshold of coercion, a cyberoperation must have the effect of 'significantly influenc[ing] or thwart[ing]' the decision-making process of a State to the point where its 'will is manifestly bent'. Although it did not specify a definite threshold that non-forcible conduct must meet to constitute an act of intervention, Switzerland noted that a cyberoperation could amount to economic coercion if it paralyzed the operation of a 'company that is systemically relevant'.
On the other hand, Poland indicated that, to constitute coercion, the foreign State's conduct must 'adversely affect' the 'functioning and security of the political, economic, military or social system of a state'. Norway also provided examples of non-forcible coercive conduct that included 'manipulating election systems', 'unduly influencing public opinion', and 'causing a temporary shutdown' of critical infrastructure.

Instead, Romania stated that an act of intervention must be intended to 'effectively change' the behavior of a State and underscored that 'there has to be a causal nexus between the coercive act and the effect on the internal or external affairs of the target State'. This review of national and regional position papers reveals that there are three points of convergence among States on the question of the thresholds that delineate the boundaries of the prohibition on intervention. First, there is a consensus that the threat or use of force always crosses the threshold of coercion. Second, there is a consensus that non-intervention is a broad rule that covers both forcible and non-forcible forms of coercion. Third, there is a consensus that there are certain forms of conduct that, by their very nature, fall below the threshold of coercion. There is no consensus, however, on a specific list or catalogue of acts that are ipso facto non-coercive. However, given the positions expressed by Western States, it is reasonable to conclude that there is at least a general concurrence on the view expressed in the Common African Position that calls to settle disputes peacefully are not coercive. Beyond that, the main point of divergence among States relates to the threshold at which non-forcible conduct amounts to coercion. Indeed, as Canada noted: 'further

This is a question of paramount importance to understanding how non-intervention applies in cyberspace and other domains. As noted above, the utility of the prohibition on intervention is that it protects States against conduct that is more serious than an infringement on the territorial sovereignty of a State but that does not rise to the level of a threat or use of force. This issue – the threshold at which non-forcible conduct amounts to coercion – has not been addressed by the ICJ and remains a subject of scholarly debate.128
Some scholars have argued that coercion is unsuited to function as an element of the prohibition on intervention, at least as it applies in cyberspace. For example, Duncan Hollis has opined that coercion may not be readily applicable to influence operations that use cyberspace to manipulate public opinion or disrupt the domestic political processes of a foreign State, such as Russia's interference in the 2016 US presidential election.129 Similarly, Ido Kilovaty has written that 'the norm of non-intervention, in its current narrow understanding, is almost irrelevant in a world where States increasingly resort to cyber operations as a method of interference [...] Coercion cannot contain the diversity of threats posed by new technologies. A new standard is, therefore, required'.130
In my view, we do not need a new standard. The challenge facing the application of the prohibition on intervention in cyberspace, and in other domains such as economic sanctions, is that there is no agreement among States on either the definition of coercion or on the minimum threshold of effects that must be met for conduct to constitute coercion. Any understanding of non-intervention must include a conceptual tool that distinguishes between unlawful intervention and lawful conduct that influences the policies of States. ## 3 Towards a Unified Threshold of Coercion
It is impossible, given the limitations of space, to comprehensively address the question of the threshold of coercion that applies to non-forcible conduct. This is a topic that requires further research. Nonetheless, in this section, this article will offer a general sketch of a threshold that could be employed to determine when non-forcible conduct amounts to coercion, thereby violating the prohibition on intervention. Specifically, this section proposes the adoption of a single, unified threshold of coercion that applies equally to both forcible and non-forcible intervention. According to this approach, non-forcible conduct would amount to coercion if its scale and effects are comparable to conduct that amounts to a violation of the prohibition on the threat or use of force.
Two considerations support this approach. The first is historical. Throughout its evolution, the prohibition on intervention was understood as a cognate of the prohibition on the threat or use of force.¹³⁴ Non-intervention was designed to extend the protections afforded to States under the prohibition on the threat or use of force to non-forcible – but no less pernicious – instruments of statecraft. The second consideration is conceptual. The definitions of coercion that appear in national position papers on the application of international law in cyberspace that some States have issued impose an unreasonably high threshold of effects that must be met for non-forcible conduct to amount to an act of intervention. At the time, States were permitted wage war or to engage in so-called measures short of war – i.e., acts of intervention – for an expansive range of reasons. These included preserving the balance of power, repelling attacks against a State's territory, preempting an imminent armed attack, obtaining reparation for injuries inflicted on the interests or honor of the State, protecting the lives and property of citizens, securing the repayment of debts, and preventing mass atrocities. ## 3.2 Coercion as Conduct Comparable to the Use of Force
In addition to being unfounded in *lex lata*, defining coercion as acts that cause a State to behave involuntarily or that deprive a State of its freedom of choice or control over matters its domestic jurisdiction is conceptually flawed for two reasons. First, it would be incoherent to apply to non-forcible intervention that is undertaken through instruments such as information operations or economic sanctions a threshold of coercion that is higher than that which applies to the use of armed force, which is the gravest form of intervention. Second, even if one were to ignore the inconsistency between the thresholds of forcible and non-forcible intervention, the definitions of coercion that apply to the latter that some States have adopted are unreasonably high and severely restrict the scope of application of the prohibition on intervention. This section addresses these two points.

Many States also underscored that the use of force is the gravest form of coercion. This reflects the principle that the prohibition on the use of force is a peremptory rule of international law. Paradoxically, however, if, as many States propose, coercion is defined as conduct that causes a State to behave involuntarily or that deprives it of freedom of choice or control, non-forcible conduct would be governed by a higher threshold than that which applies to armed intervention. For example, acts of a higher gravity are more likely to be perceived by States as of a military rather than law enforcement nature and thus as engaging their international relations [...] Also, acts of higher gravity may evince a hostile or coercive intention (discussed in the following section) with respect to another State and thus engage "international relations" on that basis'.

O'Connell, 'The True Meaning of Force' (2014) 108 AJIL Unbound 141–144, at 143 (Arguing that 'de minimis exceptions are an inherent part of many legal rules, and the long practice under the Charter since 1945 demonstrates that article 2(4) does not cover minor force').

application of the prohibition on the use of force is not subject to a gravity threshold, which means that any use of force by one State against another State – regardless of its scale and effects – is governed by this rule.173 The ICJ has not taken a definitive position on this question.174
Whatever position one takes on this matter, one thing is clear. The threshold that must be met for an act to constitute an instance of the use of force is low. Even the threshold for an armed attack, the gravest form of the use of force, is relatively low.175 As the International Law Association noted, 'it appears that the gravity threshold attached to armed attacks is not markedly high, and would include most uses of force likely to cause casualties or significant property damage'.176
Compared to the threshold of the use of force, the definitions of coercion that many States have adopted in their national position papers impose a much higher threshold of coercion for non-forcible conduct. Nothing in *jus ad bellum* requires the use of force to be of such gravity that it *significantly influences* or *thwarts* the decision-making processes of a State to the extent that its will is *manifestly bent*, which is the definition of coercion adopted by Germany. Similarly, *jus ad bellum* does not require the State to be subjected to a level of compulsion that causes it to 'act in an involuntary manner or to refrain from acting in a certain manner', which is the definition of coercion adopted by Estonia and several other States. Nor is it necessary under *jus ad bellum* for a State to be exposed to such pressure that *deprives* it of freedom of choice or *compels* or *imposes* an outcome on the State, which is the definition of coercion adopted by Canada.

In addition to the incongruence of having a threshold of coercion for non-forcible intervention that is higher than that which applies to forcible intervention, the definitions of coercion that some States have adopted impose an unreasonably high threshold for non-forcible conduct. To meet the threshold of causing a State to act involuntarily or to deprive it of freedom of choice or control over its domestic jurisdiction, the conduct of the coercing State must be of such intensity that it overwhelms the coerced State and leaves it with no viable choice but to submit to the demands of the coercing State.¹⁷⁷ In both jurisprudence and philosophy, involuntariness is generally understood as being a situation where an actor lacks a meaningful choice or has no reasonable alternative but to comply with the demands of another actor.¹⁷⁸ Applying these definitions would significantly reduce the scope of the prohibition on intervention, thereby permitting a wide-range of non-forcible conduct both in cyberspace and beyond.
Take the definition of coercion in Canada's national position paper on the application of international law in cyberspace. As noted above, Canada defined coercion as conduct that compels or imposes an outcome on the affected State or deprives it of its freedom of choice. Canada also provided the following example of an act of unlawful intervention in an election: '[a]n
¹⁷⁷ The definitions of coercion adopted by most States (coercion as conduct that causes a State to act involuntarily and coercion as conduct that deprives a State of freedom of choice or control) appear to echo the definition of coercion that the ILC adopted in its Articles on the Responsibility of States for Internationally Wrongful Acts. The ILC stated that coercion 'has the same essential character as force majeure', which it defined as a situation where the conduct of a State is 'involuntary or at least involves no element of free choice'. As the ILC explained, the degree of pressure required for a State to be placed in a position where its conduct is 'involuntary' or lacking the 'element of free choice' is one of 'irresistible force'. To be clear, States have not cited the Articles on State Responsibility as an authority to support their definitions of coercion. Nonetheless, there is a striking resemblance between the ILC's definition of coercion and the definitions adopted by many States in their position papers. In my view, this is a threshold of pressure that is far higher than anything required by the jus ad bellum. For the ILC's discussion of the concepts of coercion and force majeure, see UN ILC, 'Report of the International Law Commission: Fifty-Third Session' (23 April–1 June and 2 July–10 August 2001) GAOR 56th Session Supp. 10 (A/56/10), at 69, 77–78.

Under this definition, almost all of the conduct that appears in a recent report published by a commission established by the Canadian government to investigate foreign interference in Canadian elections would not be wrongful under the prohibition on intervention. The report, which is titled Public Inquiry into Foreign Interference in Federal Electoral Processes and Democratic Institutions, noted that foreign interference did not determine the outcome of the election. The report did, however, state the following:
The fact that foreign interference may not have impacted the outcomes in many ridings does not mean, however, that it did not impact the election. Foreign interference in 2019 and 2021 undermined the right of voters to have an electoral ecosystem free from coercion or covert influence. Foreign interference has an impact when there is a single instance where a ballot is cast in a certain way, or not cast at all, because of a foreign state's direct or indirect enticement.
The report added that this foreign interference affected the electoral ecosystem and had the overall effect of '[u]ndermining faith in democracy and government' and led to a 'reduced trust in Canada's democratic process'. Under Canada's definition of coercion, this conduct would not be unlawful. The foreign interference catalogued in this report did not impose any particular choice on Canada nor did it significantly affect the outcome of an election. Likewise, this conduct would not meet the threshold of causing a State to act involuntarily. Nonetheless, the political effects of foreign interference of this nature are serious, especially in the long-term. Failing to proscribe conduct of this nature would turn the prohibition on intervention into a normative empty shell that provides little protection to States and would permit a broad range of disruptive non-forcible behavior.
HELAL
This is why I believe that the Common African Position was right to define coercion as conduct that is designed 'to impose restraints on the will of a foreign state', which is a markedly lower threshold than that proposed by other States. The question, however, is what exactly does 'imposing restraints' entail and at what point can one say that the exertion of pressure on a State has reached the point of 'imposing restraints' on its will?
To this writer – and I must emphasize that this is the author's view, not that of the member States of the African Union – the threshold of coercion for non-forcible conduct should be defined as being comparable to the minimum effects of conduct that amounts to a threat or use of force. In other words, for non-forcible conduct – such as political, economic, or informational measures – to amount to intervention, the effects of the conduct in question should be comparable to that which is entailed by the threat or use of force. I call this the unified threshold of coercion. The practical effect of adopting the unified threshold of coercion is that any non-forcible conduct that causes effects on a scale that is comparable to conduct that amounts to a violation of the prohibition on the threat or use of force would constitute a breach of the prohibition on intervention.
To further explain, other reports by the Canadian government provide understandings of foreign interference that, to this writer, approximates the degree of effects that would meet the unified threshold of coercion, thereby amounting to a breach of the prohibition on intervention. In one report published by the National Security and Intelligence Committee of Parliamentarians, foreign interference was defined in the following terms: '[f]oreign interference involves foreign states, or persons/entities operating on their behalf, attempting to covertly influence decisions, events or outcomes to better suit their strategic interests'. This report also stated: 'foreign interference includes attempts to covertly influence, intimidate, manipulate, interfere, corrupt or discredit individuals, organizations and governments to further the interests of a foreign country'. It also underscored that 'foreign interference should be understood as a long-term effort, akin to espionage, using inducements or threats. Both dynamics enable the manipulation of targets when required, for example, through requests for inappropriate or special favours'. This report

Foreign interference activities are distinct from acceptable diplomatic advocacy and lobbying. To this writer, these reports describe the kinds of conduct that were intended to be covered by the Common African Position, and which would be covered by the unified threshold of coercion proposed here.
Two considerations lend support to this understanding of coercion. First, adopting a unified threshold of coercion that applies to both forcible and non-forcible intervention is consistent with the history of the evolution of the prohibition on intervention. Throughout the negotiations on instruments in which non-intervention was codified, States consistently viewed acts of intervention as being analogous to the use of force.^^ For example, as noted above, the drafters of the 1933 Montevideo Convention described intervention

For example, Argentina stated: 'What is intervention, then, but violence? [...] Intervention is violence.' El Salvador also affirmed that '[b]ecause the American conscience is such that territorial acquisitions originated by violence cannot be recognized; that violence has generally come to disturb the life of our countries in the form of intervention'. In addition to being consistent with the historical evolution of non-intervention, adopting a unified threshold of coercion that applies to all forms of intervention reflects the fact that non-intervention and the non-use of force share the same policy purpose. The ICJ has stated that ‘a rule of international law, whether customary or conventional, does not operate in a vacuum; it operates in relation to facts and in the context of a wider framework of legal rules of which it forms only a part’.¹⁹⁸ Writing in more colorful terms, James Crawford observed that ‘customary rules usually hunt in packs, connected by some familial relationship and interacting with each other’.¹⁹⁹
Non-intervention and the non-use of force belong to the same normative ‘pack’. These rules are part of what scholars call the ‘law of coexistence’, the policy purpose of which is to protect the autonomy of States and enable them to coexist peacefully in an anarchic international system.²⁰⁰ Specifically, these two rules – non-intervention and the non-use of force – are designed to protect the physical and functional manifestations of sovereignty. These two ‘domains’ of sovereignty – the physical and the functional – are expressed by the concepts of the ‘territorial integrity’ and ‘political independence’ of States, which appear in Article 2(4) of the UN Charter.²⁰¹ Non-intervention extended the

To be clear, the unified threshold of coercion proposed here should not be read as suggesting that non-intervention is coterminous with the prohibition on the threat or use of force. Far from it. Although both rules share the same policy purposes, the prohibition on intervention is broader than the prohibition on the threat or use of force. Non-intervention applies to any policy or practice, whether forcible and non-forcible, that impinges on the political independence or territorial integrity of States. In a sense, therefore, the prohibition on the threat or use of force should be viewed as a *lex specialis* that applies to a specific genus of intervention (namely, *armed* intervention). This body of *lex specialis* has been subsumed, *in toto*, within the broader *lex generalis* of the prohibition on intervention.
In conclusion, further research and further expressions of State views are needed on the definition and threshold of coercion. This is essential to understanding how the prohibition on intervention applies to and governs non-forcible conduct both in cyberspace and beyond. To this writer, however, the unified threshold of coercion that this article proposes provides a conceptual foundation on which to formulate a workable and conceptually coherent approach to applying the prohibition on intervention.

# Coercion in Cyberspace – Taking Stock of the Debate
Mohamed S. Helal
Associate Professor of Law, The Ohio State University, Columbus, The United States of America; Member, Permanent Court of Arbitration; Member, African Union Commission on International Law (AUCIL); Special Rapporteur of the African Union on the Application of International Law in Cyberspace
## Abstract
This article explores debates among States on the application of the prohibition on intervention in cyberspace. It focuses on coercion as an element of the prohibition on intervention and identifies the different definitions of coercion that States have adopted in national and regional position papers on the application of international law in cyberspace. This article also specifically discusses the views of States on the threshold of coercion, which is the degree of harm or the effects that the conduct of a State must cause (or threaten to cause) to amount to a violation of the prohibition on intervention. This article argues that the definitions and thresholds of coercion that States have adopted in debates on the application of international law in cyberspace should be viewed as proposals for the development of the law in this area, as opposed to restatements of established law. Instead, this article proposes that all forms of intervention should be governed by a ‘unified threshold of coercion’ that applies to both forcible and non-forcible intervention.
## Keywords
prohibition on intervention – cyberspace – coercion – prohibition on the threat or use of force
© KONINKLIJKE BRILL BV, LEIDEN, 2024 | DOI:10.1163/18757413_02701019
HELAL
# 1 Introduction
It is undisputed that the prohibition on intervention is a rule of customary international law.¹ This rule is also codified in numerous conventions, including the founding instruments of several regional organizations.² Non-intervention was also applied by the International Court of Justice (ICJ) in several cases,³ the most important of which is the Nicaragua Case.⁴ This rule was also reaffirmed in many UN General Assembly resolutions,⁵ the most notable of which is the 1970 Declaration on Principles of International Law Concerning Friendly Relations and Co-Operation Among States in Accordance with the Charter of the United Nations ('1970 Friendly Relations Declaration').⁶ The prohibition on intervention also appears in the 1949 Declaration on the Rights and Duties of States and the 1954 Code of Offenses Against the Peace and Security of Mankind which were adopted by the International Law Commission (ILC).⁷

COERCION IN CYBERSPACE - TAKING STOCK OF THE DEBATE Invocations of the principle of non-intervention are also ubiquitous in diplomatic practice. States from every region and from every political bloc have accused their adversaries (and sometimes even their allies) of intervening in their affairs.[8] In recent years, there has been a growing interest among States and scholars in the principle of non-intervention. One reason is that cyberspace has become a domain of conflict and competition. Information and communication technologies (ICTs) are being used both as weapons of war and as instruments of non-forcible intervention.[9] States, state-sponsored non-State actors, and non-State groups and individuals acting independently have employed ICTs against foreign States, citizens, and companies to achieve various political, economic, criminal, scientific, and financial objectives. ICTs have been used to disrupt critical infrastructure, spread disinformation and propaganda to sow social discord, interfere in elections, acquire industrial and trade secrets, steal scientific research and intellectual property, and to gain profit through activities such as ransomware attacks. As a result, there is a growing corpus of state practice and expressions of opinio juris, in addition to a sizable body of scholarship, on how the prohibition on intervention applies in cyberspace. This article engages with these discussions.
Specifically, this article has two objectives. First, it explores how States have defined the concept of coercion,[10] which is considered a core component of HELAL the prohibition on intervention.¹¹ It also examines how States have demarcated the boundary between, on one hand, the prohibition on intervention and, on the other, the obligation to respect the territorial sovereignty of States and the prohibition on the threat or use of force, which are two rules that are closely associated with the prohibition on intervention.
This article will do so by surveying national and regional position papers that States have issued in recent years on the application of international law in cyberspace in which States have outlined their views on the scope and content of the prohibition on intervention and on how it governs the conduct of States in cyberspace. These position papers were issued, at least partially, in response to calls by the UN Open-Ended Working Group on Developments in the Field of Information and Telecommunications in the Context of International Security (OEWG) for States to express their opinions on how international law applies in cyberspace.¹² The OEWG is one of the two principal forums in which discussions at the UN on the regulation of cyberspace are conducted, the other being the UN Group of Governmental Experts on Advancing Responsible State Behaviour in Cyberspace in the Context of International Security (GGE).¹³ In addition to being of interest to scholars who specialize in the regulation of cyberspace, these national and regional position papers also deserve special attention from generalist scholars of international law. Most of these position papers are not framed as expressions of State views on *lex specialis* that apply only in cyberspace. Rather, they contain detailed statements on the scope and content of a wide range of *lex generalis* followed by discussions on how these rules of general international law apply in cyberspace. This makes these position papers a rich source of *opinio juris* on various primary and secondary rules ¹¹ p. 11 A. Tzanakopoulos, ‘The Right to be Free from Economic Coercion’ (2015) 4 Cambridge Journal of International Law 616–633, at 620 (‘Coercion is a method of illegal intervention [...] coercion is intervention. Seeking to coerce a state within its sphere of freedom is wrongful; it constitutes intervention’).
¹² UNGA, ‘Open-Ended Working Group on Developments in the Field of Information and Telecommunications in the Context of International Security – Final Substantive Report’ (10 March 2021) UN Doc. A/AC.290/2021/CRP.2, at para. 38. (The OEWG recommended that ‘States, on a voluntary basis, continue to inform the Secretary-General of their national views and assessments on how international law applies to their use of ICTs in the context of international security, and continue to voluntarily share such national views and practices through other avenues as appropriate’).
¹³ See C. Painter, ‘The United Nations’ Cyberstability Processes: Surprising Progress but Much Left to Do’ (2021) 6 Journal of Cyber Policy 271–276.
COERCION IN CYBERSPACE - TAKING STOCK OF THE DEBATE of international law, many of which are foundational to the international legal order. Some of the rules covered by these position papers include sovereignty, the prohibition on the threat or use of force, the peaceful settlement of disputes, human rights, the laws of armed conflict, the rules of attribution, and of course, the prohibition on intervention, which is the subject of this article.
Examining these national and regional position papers on the application of international law in cyberspace reveals that, while the prohibition on intervention is accepted as a rule of general international law, there remains considerable uncertainty regarding the exact scope and content of this rule. In particular, there are notable differences among States on the definition of coercion. Some States have defined coercion as conduct that modifies the behavior of a State by causing it to act involuntarily or by compelling it to act in a manner that it would not have voluntarily engaged in but for the coercive conduct of a foreign State. Other States have defined coercion as conduct that deprives a State of its freedom of choice or control over matters within its domestic jurisdiction. A third and broader approach, which was adopted by the African Union, defines coercion as any conduct that imposes restraints on the will of a foreign State.
In addition to articulating theoretical definitions of coercion, some States provided examples of conduct that, in their view, amounted to coercion. These examples shed further light on how the concept of coercion applies to real-world situations in which ICTs are used as instruments of statecraft. In particular, these examples clarify the views of States on the threshold of effects or the degree of pressure that a State must be subjected to in order for conduct to be considered coercive. As I show below, there is currently no consensus among States on the effects that the conduct of the coercing State must have on the coerced State to constitute an act of unlawful intervention. Some States adopted relatively high thresholds that require the conduct in question to have significant effects on the coerced State. For example, for some States, merely seeking to sway public opinion during an election campaign does not necessarily amount to unlawful intervention. Rather, to those States, electoral interference must rise to the level of altering election results or preventing a segment of the population from voting in order to constitute an act of intervention.[14] On the other hand, other States adopted lower thresholds to determine when HELAL electoral interference could be deemed coercive. For example, one State noted that 'hack and leak' operations to influence public opinion could constitute a violation of the prohibition on intervention.¹⁵ The African Union also adopted a relatively low threshold of coercion that does not require the behavior of a foreign State to have significant effects on a State in order to amount to unlawful intervention.
In short, national and regional position papers on the application of international law in cyberspace indicate that there are divergences among States on how the prohibition on intervention governs state conduct in cyberspace. There is no agreement on a theoretical definition of coercion, there is no consensus on the threshold of effects that determines when specific state conduct that is designed to influence the behavior of other States constitutes coercion, and there is some uncertainty on how non-intervention relates to other rules such as the prohibition on the threat or use of force and the obligation to respect the territorial sovereignty of States.
Having catalogued the views that States have, heretofore, expressed on non-intervention and coercion in cyberspace, the second objective of this article is to critically appraise the understandings of coercion that States have adopted in their national and regional position papers. Specifically, this article makes the following two arguments.
First, this article contends that – as a matter of formal law – the positions expressed by States on the meaning of coercion should be viewed as proposals de lege ferenda, and not as restatements of established lex lata. This is because, as I explain below, nothing in the history of the development of the prohibition of intervention lends support to the definitions of coercion that States have espoused. Then, building on decades of advocacy principally by non-aligned States, the prohibition on intervention became a rule of general international law with the adoption of the 1970 Friendly Relations Declaration. However, at no point during the evolution of the prohibition on intervention did States define coercion as conduct that causes a State to behave involuntarily or that deprives a State of its freedom of choice or control over matters within its domestic jurisdiction. Second, this article argues that the definitions of coercion adopted by some States are conceptually flawed. Echoing the ICJ's judgment in the Nicaragua Case,¹⁶ virtually all States agree that the prohibition on intervention proscribes coercion whether undertaken through armed force or through non-forcible means, such as economic or political instruments of statecraft. Many States also underscored that the use of armed force is the gravest form of intervention. Yet – paradoxically – applying the definitions of coercion espoused by many (especially Western) States would lead to a situation where the gravest form of intervention – armed force – is governed by a lower threshold than non-forcible forms of intervention that are considered less grave.
As discussed below, nothing in *jus ad bellum* requires an act that amounts to armed intervention to be of such gravity that it causes a State to behave involuntarily or deprives it of control over matters within its domestic jurisdiction, which are the definitions of coercion adopted by some States. Indeed, attacking a single military unit could constitute a violation of the prohibition on the threat or use of force and could even amount to an armed attack,¹⁷ regardless of its effect on the behavior of the target State. On the other hand, applying the definitions of coercion adopted by some States would require non-forcible forms of intervention to reach a level of gravity and intensity that causes (or threatens to cause) a State to act involuntarily or that deprives it of freedom of choice. Therefore, this article argues that States and scholars should consider adopting what I call the 'unified threshold of coercion' that applies to both forcible and non-forcible intervention. Based on this approach, non-forcible conduct would be considered coercive if its impact is comparable to the scale and effects of conduct that amounts to a violation of the threat or use of force. This unified threshold of coercion is lower than the thresholds of coercion that many States have adopted in their position papers on the application of international law in cyberspace.
This article consists of two sections. Section 1 provides a survey of the definitions of coercion that appear in national and regional position papers on the application of international law in cyberspace. This section also outlines the views of States on the interconnection between non-intervention and the prohibition on the use of force and the obligation to respect state sovereignty, which is a debate that sheds further light on the kinds of conduct that each of these rules applies to and regulates. Then in Section 2, this article critically appraises the understandings of coercion adopted by States and argues in favor of adopting what I call the 'unified threshold of coercion' that applies equally to both forcible and non-forcible forms of intervention.

## 2.2 Coercion as Conduct that Deprives a State of Freedom of Choice or Control
The second understanding of coercion that has emerged out of national position papers on the application of international law in cyberspace defines coercion as an act that deprives a State of its ability to control or to exercise freedom of choice regarding matters within its domaine réservé. Australia adopted this view. Its position paper stated: ‘[c]oercive means are those that effectively deprive or are intended to deprive the State of the ability to control, decide upon or govern matters of an inherently sovereign nature’.44 In order to establish that a breach of the prohibition on intervention has indeed occurred, Australia required evidence that the conduct of the coercing State had some measurable impact or discernable effect on the target State.45 Canada expressed a similar position. Its position paper explained that a cyberoperation would be coercive if it is ‘designed to deprive the affected State of its freedom of choice’.46 Canada also noted that, in order to amount to an act of

HELAL intervention, a cyberoperation must 'cause coercive effects that deprive, compel or otherwise impose an outcome on the affected State'.47 New Zealand also defined coercion as conduct that manifests 'an intention to deprive the target state of control over matters falling within the scope of its inherently sovereign functions'.48 According to New Zealand, to constitute intervention, the conduct of the coercing State must have 'significant effects' on a matter within a State's domaine réservé. It stated: Coercion is an activity intended to deprive, either directly or indirectly, the State of its ability to exercise control or govern matters within its internal and external affairs [...] The difference between actions that violate sovereignty and actions that violate the prohibition of intervention is that the latter is coercive, i.e., intentionally aims to influence the State's free will and choice.49 Brazil, Costa Rica, and the UK also adopted similar definitions of coercion. In some respects, the understanding of coercion in the Common African Position is similar to other definitions of coercion, but it also diverges from these definitions in significant ways. The Common African Position defined coercion as conduct that ‘impose[s] restraints on the will of a foreign State’. This is broadly analogous to the notion of impinging on the freedom of choice of States, which is central to the coercion-as-control model. However, the Common African Position also indicates that the purpose of intervention is to ‘influence the conduct of a foreign State’. This echoes definitions that understand coercion as conduct that aims at modifying the behavior of a State by subverting, manipulating, or undermining its decision-making processes.
Compared to other definitions of coercion, however, the Common African Position was purposively designed to broaden the protective scope of the prohibition on intervention. It does so by adopting a lower threshold of (actual or threatened) effects that must be crossed for conduct to amount to coercion. This is clearly expressed in the following sentence: ‘the African Union is of the view that it is not necessary, in order to constitute coercion, that the conduct of a State must rise to the level of completely depriving a foreign State of its freedom of choice or to compel that State to either act or refrain from acting involuntarily’.⁶⁵ In other words, the principal point of divergence between the Common African Position and the positions of other States relates to the threshold of coercion. For the member States of the African Union, intervention is any conduct undertaken by a State that imposes restraints on another State in relation to matters within its domestic jurisdiction. However, those restraints need not be of such severity that they cause a State to act involuntarily nor do they need to reach a level of intensity that completely deprives that State of its freedom of choice or control over matters within its domestic jurisdiction.
It is notable that, in an initial draft of the Common African Position that this author had prepared while serving as the African Union Special Rapporteur on the Application of International Law in Cyberspace, coercion was defined in the following terms: ‘coercion, in the context of the prohibition on intervention, should be defined as a policy that is designed to impose material restraints on the will of a foreign State’. The member States determined that the word 'restraints' sufficiently and accurately captured the essence of the prohibition on intervention. Many States described non-intervention as a rule that is intended to protect the policy autonomy of States and to enable States to manage their internal and external affairs free from 'restraints' that might be imposed by other States. The AU member States also agreed that, when read in the context of the entire section on non-intervention in the Common African Position, the prohibition on intervention was not over-inclusive.

Its position paper affirmed that the 'coercive intention of the state actor is a critical element of the rule' and underscored that 'intention may in some circumstances be inferred from the effects of cyber activity'.⁶⁸ Similarly, Costa Rica's position paper noted that '[f]or such breaches [of the prohibition on intervention] to occur, it suffices that a State intends to coerce another State, employs coercive methods, or eventually causes coercive effects in another State'.⁶⁹ Czechia's position paper used similar terms. For instance, Norway stated that holding elections is an example of an activity that falls within the *domaine réservé* of a State. The use of the term *'designed'* by these position papers introduces the element of intent into the definition of coercion. It indicates that the coercing State is acting purposefully and intentionally and employing its resources in a systematic and strategic manner to achieve specific policy objectives.
Other States used similar phrases that also make the intent of the coercing State an element of the definition of coercion. The Netherlands and Romania defined coercion as conduct *'the goal'* of which is changing the behavior of the target State. Likewise, Estonia and Poland described coercion as conduct that *'aimed'* at achieving a specific objective. Estonia, for example, stated that 'cyber operations that *aim* to force another nation to act in an involuntary manner or to refrain from acting in a certain manner' would amount to intervention.[77] Poland also stated that '[t]o be in breach of international law, HELAL an intervention must include the element of coercion that aims at influencing the state's decisions belonging to its domaine réservé.78 Again, using phrases like: 'the goal of' intervention, or saying that coercion is conduct 'that aims at', presupposes that the coercing State is acting intentionally. It indicates that the coercing State has identified a policy objective – an aim or a goal – which it is seeking to achieve by engaging in cyberoperations against another State.
## 2.5 Sovereignty, Intervention, and the Use of Force: Demarcating the Doctrinal Boundaries In addition to articulating definitions of coercion and offering examples of conduct that amounts to coercion, many States addressed the question of the relation between, on one hand, the prohibition on intervention and, on the other, the obligation to respect the territorial sovereignty of States and the prohibition on the threat or use of force. The content and scope of application of these three rules overlap significantly. As the ICJ observed in the Nicaragua Case, '[t]he effects of the principle of respect for territorial sovereignty inevitably overlap with those of the principles of the prohibition of the use of force and of non-intervention'.79 To disentangle the interconnection between these three rules, many States expressed views on the threshold of effects that must be crossed for conduct to amount to a violation of each of these rules. Surveying national and regional position papers on the application of international law in cyberspace reveals that States have approached this question from three different angles. The first relates to categories of conduct that – by their very nature – do not constitute a breach of the prohibition on intervention because they fall below the threshold of coercion. Nonetheless, some States noted that conduct that does not amount to intervention because it falls below the threshold of coercion may still be wrongful because it violates the principle of state sovereignty. The second is the higher threshold of coercion, which many States identified as the point at which non-intervention intersects with the prohibition on the threat or use of force. The third relates to the threshold at which non-forcible conduct – such as information operations, election interference, or economic sanctions – amount to coercion.

## 2.8 The Threshold of Non-forcible Coercion This question of the exact threshold at which non-forcible conduct amounts to coercion is of critical importance. This is because most acts of unlawful intervention that could be undertaken through cyberspace are likely to fall below the threshold of forcible intervention. For example, activities such as election interference or disinformation campaigns will almost always fall below the threshold of the use of force.¹⁰⁸ In fact, this is precisely the area – conduct below the threshold of the use of force, but above the threshold of violations of territorial sovereignty – where the prohibition on intervention is most relevant.

This lack of consistency is evident even among States that adopted the same definition of coercion. In other words, even where there is some convergence among States on the meaning of coercion at a theoretical level, there are notable divergences on how the concept of coercion applies in real-world situations.
Among the States that defined coercion as conduct that modifies the behavior of a State or causes it to act involuntarily, there were notable differences in the terminology used to describe the threshold that applies to non-forcible coercion. Germany contended that, to constitute an act of intervention, a cyberoperation must be 'comparable in scale and effect to coercion in non-cyber contexts'. According to Germany, to meet the threshold of coercion, a cyberoperation must have the effect of 'significantly influenc[ing] or thwart[ing]' the decision-making process of a State to the point where its 'will is manifestly bent'.[109] Although it did not specify a definite threshold that non-forcible conduct must meet to constitute an act of intervention, Switzerland noted that a cyberoperation could amount to economic coercion if it paralyzed the operation of a 'company that is systemically relevant'.[110] On the other hand, Poland indicated that, to constitute coercion, the foreign State's conduct must 'adversely affect' the 'functioning and security of the political, economic, military or social system of a state'.[111] Norway also provided examples of non-forcible coercive conduct that included 'manipulating election systems', 'unduly influencing public opinion', and 'causing a temporary shutdown' of critical infrastructure.[112] Denmark and Romania, both of which also defined coercion as conduct that modifies the behavior of a State or causes it to act involuntarily, did not explicitly identify a specific threshold at which non-forcible conduct could be considered coercive. Instead, Romania stated that an act of intervention must be intended to 'effectively change' the behavior of a State and underscored that 'there has to be a causal nexus between the coercive act and the effect on the internal or external affairs of the target State'.[113] Denmark's position paper also stated that 'an act may be considered of a coercive nature when the act HELAL of interference has a potential for compelling the target State to engage in an action that it would otherwise not take.¹¹⁴ To this writer, the thresholds of coercion adopted by Germany and Switzerland are substantially higher than the thresholds adopted by Poland and Norway. The phrase ‘significantly influencing or thwarting’ that was used by Germany and the words ‘paralysis’ and ‘systemically relevant’ that Switzerland used signify a notably higher threshold of coercion than the term ‘adverse effects’ that was used by Poland and the phrases ‘manipulating election systems’ and ‘unduly influencing public opinion’ that Norway used. Denmark appears to have adopted an even lower threshold of coercion. For Denmark, a cyberoperation need not have an actual effect on the target State to be considered wrongful under the prohibition on intervention. Rather, a cyberoperation that merely has the ‘potential for compelling’ a State crosses the threshold of coercion. On the other hand, for Romania, the ‘potential’ to compel a State is insufficient. Rather, to constitute intervention, Romania requires that a State must be the target of a cyberoperation that has a measurable effect on the coerced State and that is causally connected to the behavior of the coercing State.
