As noted above, the Common African Position did not identify a specific threshold at which non-forcible conduct amounts to coercion. Rather, the Common African Position noted that the definition of coercion requires further study among States, and explicitly rejected the thresholds that other States adopted in their position papers. The Common African Position stated: 'it is not necessary, in order to constitute coercion, that the conduct of a State must rise to the level of completely depriving a foreign State of its freedom of choice or to compel that State to either act or refrain from acting involuntarily'.[126] This review of national and regional position papers reveals that there are three points of convergence among States on the question of the thresholds that delineate the boundaries of the prohibition on intervention. First, there is a consensus that the threat or use of force always crosses the threshold of coercion. Second, there is a consensus that non-intervention is a broad rule that covers both forcible and non-forcible forms of coercion. Third, there is a consensus that there are certain forms of conduct that, by their very nature, fall below the threshold of coercion. There is no consensus, however, on a specific list or catalogue of acts that are ipso facto non-coercive. However, given the positions expressed by Western States, it is reasonable to conclude that there is at least a general concurrence on the view expressed in the Common African Position that calls to settle disputes peacefully are not coercive. Beyond that, the main point of divergence among States relates to the threshold at which non-forcible conduct amounts to coercion. Indeed, as Canada noted: 'further COERCION IN CYBERSPACE - TAKING STOCK OF THE DEBATE State practice and opinio juris will help clarify the thresholds for the rule of non-intervention, and the scope of customary law in this area over time'.127 This is a question of paramount importance to understanding how non-intervention applies in cyberspace and other domains. As noted above, the utility of the prohibition on intervention is that it protects States against conduct that is more serious than an infringement on the territorial sovereignty of a State but that does not rise to the level of a threat or use of force. This issue – the threshold at which non-forcible conduct amounts to coercion – has not been addressed by the ICJ and remains a subject of scholarly debate.128 Some scholars have argued that coercion is unsuited to function as an element of the prohibition on intervention, at least as it applies in cyberspace. For example, Duncan Hollis has opined that coercion may not be readily applicable to influence operations that use cyberspace to manipulate public opinion or disrupt the domestic political processes of a foreign State, such as Russia's interference in the 2016 US presidential election.129 Similarly, Ido Kilovaty has written that 'the norm of non-intervention, in its current narrow understanding, is almost irrelevant in a world where States increasingly resort to cyber operations as a method of interference [...] Coercion cannot contain the diversity of threats posed by new technologies. A new standard is, therefore, required'.130 In my view, we do not need a new standard. The challenge facing the application of the prohibition on intervention in cyberspace, and in other domains such as economic sanctions, is that there is no agreement among States on either the definition of coercion or on the minimum threshold of effects that must be met for conduct to constitute coercion. Any understanding of non-intervention must include a conceptual tool that distinguishes between unlawful intervention and lawful conduct that influences the policies of States. Whether that conceptual tool is called 'coercion', 'dictatorial interference',131 HELAL ‘imperative pressure’,¹³² ‘forcible compulsion or restraint’,¹³³ or any other term is immaterial. What matters is the threshold of effects that defines and captures the essence of ‘coercion’, which can be applied to determine when specific conduct amounts to intervention. This is the question that Section 3 of this article addresses.
## 3 Towards a Unified Threshold of Coercion It is impossible, given the limitations of space, to comprehensively address the question of the threshold of coercion that applies to non-forcible conduct. This is a topic that requires further research. Nonetheless, in this section, this article will offer a general sketch of a threshold that could be employed to determine when non-forcible conduct amounts to coercion, thereby violating the prohibition on intervention. Specifically, this section proposes the adoption of a single, unified threshold of coercion that applies equally to both forcible and non-forcible intervention. According to this approach, non-forcible conduct would amount to coercion if its scale and effects are comparable to conduct that amounts to a violation of the prohibition on the threat or use of force.
Two considerations support this approach. The first is historical. Throughout its evolution, the prohibition on intervention was understood as a cognate of the prohibition on the threat or use of force.¹³⁴ Non-intervention was designed to extend the protections afforded to States under the prohibition on the threat or use of force to non-forcible – but no less pernicious – instruments of statecraft. The second consideration is conceptual. The definitions of coercion that appear in national position papers on the application of international law in cyberspace that some States have issued impose an unreasonably high threshold of effects that must be met for non-forcible conduct to amount to an act of intervention. COERCION IN CYBERSPACE - TAKING STOCK OF THE DEBATE Before proceeding, one point merits special emphasis. The unified threshold of coercion that I propose here should not be understood as signaling that the prohibition on the use of force and the prohibition on intervention are coterminous. At least one writer has recently suggested that ‘under the *lex lata* the prohibition on intervention only applies to acts amounting to a use of force or constituting support for the violent overthrow of a foreign regime’.¹³⁵ I disagree. As discussed below, at least since the adoption of the 1970 Friendly Relations Declaration, there has been a consensus among States that non-intervention is a broad rule that proscribes all forms of intervention, whether undertaken through forcible or non-forcible means. However, because there is no agreement among States on the meaning of coercion, there is continued uncertainty regarding when non-forcible conduct amounts to unlawful intervention. The unified threshold of coercion addresses this question by proposing a single test that applies to all forms of intervention, including armed force, or the use of political, economic, or informational instruments of statecraft, or some combination thereof.
## 3.1 Coercion in the History of the Prohibition on Intervention As argued in detail in another study by the present author, until the *Nicaragua Case* was decided by the ICJ in 1986, the concept of coercion was not defined, nor was it viewed as the cornerstone of the prohibition on intervention.¹³⁶ Moreover, throughout its evolution, States never understood intervention as conduct that causes a State to act involuntarily or that deprives it of its freedom of choice or control over its domestic jurisdiction. This overview begins with three Inter-American treaties that first included non-intervention as a distinct rule of international law, followed by the 1970 Friendly Relations Declaration, the adoption of which marked the acceptance of the prohibition on intervention as a rule of general international law.
The prohibition on intervention originated as a rule of conventional international law in the Inter-American system. It was first codified in Article 8 of the 1933 Montevideo Convention on the Rights and Duties of States, which reads as follows: 'No State has the right to intervene in the internal or external affairs of another'.[137] The prohibition on intervention was further reaffirmed and its scope was expanded with the adoption of the 1936 Additional Protocol Relative to Non-Intervention, Article I of which states: 'The High Contracting Parties declare inadmissible the intervention of any one of them, directly or indirectly, and for whatever reason, in the internal or external affairs of any other of the Parties'.[138] The principal purpose of these provisions was to overturn the right of States to resort to acts of intervention, which was established under 19th century international law. At the time, States were permitted wage war or to engage in so-called measures short of war – i.e., acts of intervention – for an expansive range of reasons.[139] These included preserving the balance of power, repelling attacks against a State's territory, preempting an imminent armed attack, obtaining reparation for injuries inflicted on the interests or honor of the State, protecting the lives and property of citizens, securing the repayment of debts, and preventing mass atrocities.[140] Intervention was accepted as permissible COERCION IN CYBERSPACE - TAKING STOCK OF THE DEBATE because it was predicated on the right of self-preservation,¹⁴¹ which was recognized as a fundamental right of States.¹⁴² Given that they were often the target of forcible and non-forcible acts of intervention by the European powers and the United States,¹⁴³ Latin American States and scholars championed the cause of codifying an absolute prohibition on intervention as a rule of international law in the Inter-American system.¹⁴⁴ This objective was achieved with the adoption of the 1933 Montevideo Convention, the 1936 Non-Intervention Protocol, and the 1948 Charter of the Organization of American States, which included the broadest formulation of the prohibition on intervention.
During the negotiations on the 1933 Montevideo Convention and the 1936 Non-Intervention Protocol, coercion was not defined; it was not identified as a constituent element of the prohibition on intervention, nor were acts of intervention understood as involving conduct that causes a State to behave involuntarily or that deprives a State of freedom of choice or control over its domain réservé.¹⁴⁵ Indeed, the term 'coercion' does not even appear in either of these treaties. However, during the negotiations on the 1933 Montevideo Convention, a subcommittee composed of Brazil, Colombia, Cuba, Ecuador, El-Salvador, Haiti, and Peru that had been entrusted with drafting the convention prepared a report that provides an insight into how the negotiating parties understood the term 'intervention'. In its report, the subcommittee defined 'the juridical concept of intervention' as follows: Any act of a State, through diplomatic representation, by armed force, or by any other means involving effective force, with a view to making the State's will dominate the will of another State, and, in general, any maneuver, interference or interposition of any sort, employing such means, either directly or indirectly in matter of the obligations of another State, whatever its motive, shall be considered as Intervention, and likewise a violation of International Law.

## Article 20

Article 19 of the OAS Charter includes two sentences, the first of which is virtually identical to Article 1 of 1936 Non-Intervention Protocol, which itself was based on Article 8 of the 1933 Montevideo Convention. Like its antecedents, the principal purpose of the first sentence of Article 19 was to reaffirm that, at least in Inter-American international law, the right of intervention that was recognized in 19th century international law was abolished. The inclusion of the phrase 'for whatever reason', which first appeared in the 1936 Non-Intervention Protocol, also indicated that non-intervention was an absolute rule that admitted no exceptions. Accordingly, the grounds that had previously been invoked to justify intervention – such as protecting citizens abroad, collecting debts, or enforcing international law – were no longer valid.
The second sentence of Article 19 clarified a principle that was only implicit in the 1933 Montevideo Convention and the 1936 Non-Intervention Protocol. It confirmed that non-intervention proscribed both the use of armed force and any other instrument of statecraft to engage in acts of intervention. Although, as noted above, the subcommittee that drafted the 1933 Montevideo Convention had affirmed that intervention could be undertaken 'through diplomatic representation, by armed force, or any other means involving effective force', this was not explicitly stated in either the 1933 Montevideo Convention or the 1936 Non-Intervention Protocol. The second sentence of Article 19 was also intended to prohibit acts of subversion that seek to impinge on the political independence of a State by subjugating it or transforming it into a satellite of a foreign power or that undermine its capacity to manage its political, economic, and cultural affairs autonomously.[152]

## 3.2 Coercion as Conduct Comparable to the Use of Force
In addition to being unfounded in *lex lata*, defining coercion as acts that cause a State to behave involuntarily or that deprive a State of its freedom of choice or control over matters its domestic jurisdiction is conceptually flawed for two reasons. First, it would be incoherent to apply to non-forcible intervention that is undertaken through instruments such as information operations or economic sanctions a threshold of coercion that is higher than that which applies to the use of armed force, which is the gravest form of intervention. Second, even if one were to ignore the inconsistency between the thresholds of forcible and non-forcible intervention, the definitions of coercion that apply to the latter that some States have adopted are unreasonably high and severely restrict the scope of application of the prohibition on intervention. This section addresses these two points.
As noted above, virtually all position papers on the application of international law in cyberspace affirmed that the threat or use of force is *ipso facto* coercive. Many States also underscored that the use of force is the gravest form of coercion. This reflects the principle that the prohibition on the use of force is a peremptory rule of international law. Paradoxically, however, if, as many States propose, coercion is defined as conduct that causes a State to behave involuntarily or that deprives it of freedom of choice or control, non-forcible conduct would be governed by a higher threshold than that which applies to armed intervention. The threshold that must be met for an act to constitute an instance of the use of force is low. Even the threshold for an armed attack, the gravest form of the use of force, is relatively low.175 As the International Law Association noted, 'it appears that the gravity threshold attached to armed attacks is not markedly high, and would include most uses of force likely to cause casualties or significant property damage'.176 Compared to the threshold of the use of force, the definitions of coercion that many States have adopted in their national position papers impose a much higher threshold of coercion for non-forcible conduct. Nothing in *jus ad bellum* requires the use of force to be of such gravity that it *significantly influences* or *thwarts* the decision-making processes of a State to the extent that its will is *manifestly bent*, which is the definition of coercion adopted by Germany. Similarly, *jus ad bellum* does not require the State to be subjected to a level of compulsion that causes it to 'act in an involuntary manner or to refrain from acting in a certain manner', which is the definition of coercion adopted by Estonia and several other States. Nor is it necessary under *jus ad bellum* for a State to be exposed to such pressure that *deprives* it of freedom of choice or *compels* or *imposes* an outcome on the State, which is the definition of coercion adopted by Canada.

HELAL In addition to the incongruence of having a threshold of coercion for non-forcible intervention that is higher than that which applies to forcible intervention, the definitions of coercion that some States have adopted impose an unreasonably high threshold for non-forcible conduct. To meet the threshold of causing a State to act involuntarily or to deprive it of freedom of choice or control over its domestic jurisdiction, the conduct of the coercing State must be of such intensity that it overwhelms the coerced State and leaves it with no viable choice but to submit to the demands of the coercing State.¹⁷⁷ In both jurisprudence and philosophy, involuntariness is generally understood as being a situation where an actor lacks a meaningful choice or has no reasonable alternative but to comply with the demands of another actor.¹⁷⁸ Applying these definitions would significantly reduce the scope of the prohibition on intervention, thereby permitting a wide-range of non-forcible conduct both in cyberspace and beyond.

As noted above, Canada defined coercion as conduct that compels or imposes an outcome on the affected State or deprives it of its freedom of choice. The question, however, is what exactly does 'imposing restraints' entail and at what point can one say that the exertion of pressure on a State has reached the point of 'imposing restraints' on its will?
To this writer – and I must emphasize that this is the author's view, not that of the member States of the African Union – the threshold of coercion for non-forcible conduct should be defined as being comparable to the minimum effects of conduct that amounts to a threat or use of force. In other words, for non-forcible conduct – such as political, economic, or informational measures – to amount to intervention, the effects of the conduct in question should be comparable to that which is entailed by the threat or use of force. I call this the unified threshold of coercion. The practical effect of adopting the unified threshold of coercion is that any non-forcible conduct that causes effects on a scale that is comparable to conduct that amounts to a violation of the prohibition on the threat or use of force would constitute a breach of the prohibition on intervention.

Both dynamics enable the manipulation of targets when required, for example, through requests for inappropriate or special favours'.[185] This report COERCION IN CYBERSPACE - TAKING STOCK OF THE DEBATE provided examples of behavior that would not amount to unlawful intervention. These include: Foreign interference activities are distinct from acceptable diplomatic advocacy and lobbying. The latter activities are known to the host state and occur through recognized channels to achieve specific policy outcomes or objectives. It is normal for foreign diplomats in Canada, for example, to reach out to elected officials across the political spectrum, to pressure policymakers, to use local media to promote their national interests or to engage with and support domestic organizations.^[186]^ An earlier report, also published by the National Security and Intelligence Committee of Parliamentarians of Canada, states the following: '[f]oreign interference activities can include using deceptive means to cultivate relationships with elected officials and others perceived to processes influence in the political process; seek to influence the reporting of Canadian media outlets; seek, in some cases, to affect the outcome of elections; and coerce or induce diaspora communities to advance foreign interests in Canada'.^[187]^ The understandings of foreign interference in these reports are palpably broader than the definition of coercion in most national position papers on the application of international law in cyberspace, including Canada's. To this writer, these reports describe the kinds of conduct that were intended to be covered by the Common African Position, and which would be covered by the unified threshold of coercion proposed here.
Two considerations lend support to this understanding of coercion. First, adopting a unified threshold of coercion that applies to both forcible and non-forcible intervention is consistent with the history of the evolution of the prohibition on intervention. Throughout the negotiations on instruments in which non-intervention was codified, States consistently viewed acts of intervention as being analogous to the use of force.^[188]^ For example, as noted above, the drafters of the 1933 Montevideo Convention described intervention HELAL as any act that amounts to 'effective force'. It indicates that the authors of the Montevideo Convention understood non-forcible intervention to be the functional equivalent of armed force.
Moreover, during the debates on the Montevideo Convention, several Latin American States underscored that non-intervention was closely associated to the prohibition on the use of force. For example, Argentina stated: 'What is intervention, then, but violence? [...] Intervention is violence.'[189] El Salvador also affirmed that '[b]ecause the American conscience is such that territorial acquisitions originated by violence cannot be recognized; that violence has generally come to disturb the life of our countries in the form of intervention'.[190] Peru also emphasized that 'war is proscribed, so is violence, but not the use of arms, the diplomatic measures or any other means of effective compulsion'.[191] Ecuador also highlighted that '[w]hat is intervention but a kind of war, disguised and wary' and argued that, having outlawed aggression pursuant to the 1933 Anti-War Treaty of Non-Aggression and Conciliation, it was only natural for the States of the western hemisphere to proscribe intervention.[192] Similarly, during the negotiations on the OAS Charter, Cuba called economic coercion 'treacherous, silent, and underhanded aggression'.[193] Many States expressed similar views during the negotiations on both the 1965 Declaration on Non-Intervention and the 1970 Friendly Relations Declaration. For example, Guinea described intervention as a 'more pernicious' form of aggression,[194] Trinidad and Tobago called it 'subtle and insidious' aggression,[195] and the Congo argued that non-intervention covered 'political pressure, subversive activities, and other acts of aggression'.[196] Furthermore, throughout debates on non-intervention at the UN, many States frequently described non-intervention as being derivable from or a corollary of the non-use of force.[197] In short, in addition to outlawing intervention through armed COERCION IN CYBERSPACE - TAKING STOCK OF THE DEBATE force, the prohibition on intervention was designed to protect States against non-forceful conduct that was viewed as being functionally equivalent to the use of force – i.e., conduct that entailed a degree of pressure that is comparable to the use of armed force.
In addition to being consistent with the historical evolution of non-intervention, adopting a unified threshold of coercion that applies to all forms of intervention reflects the fact that non-intervention and the non-use of force share the same policy purpose. The ICJ has stated that ‘a rule of international law, whether customary or conventional, does not operate in a vacuum; it operates in relation to facts and in the context of a wider framework of legal rules of which it forms only a part’.¹⁹⁸ Writing in more colorful terms, James Crawford observed that ‘customary rules usually hunt in packs, connected by some familial relationship and interacting with each other’.¹⁹⁹ Non-intervention and the non-use of force belong to the same normative ‘pack’. These rules are part of what scholars call the ‘law of coexistence’, the policy purpose of which is to protect the autonomy of States and enable them to coexist peacefully in an anarchic international system.²⁰⁰ Specifically, these two rules – non-intervention and the non-use of force – are designed to protect the physical and functional manifestations of sovereignty. These two ‘domains’ of sovereignty – the physical and the functional – are expressed by the concepts of the ‘territorial integrity’ and ‘political independence’ of States, which appear in Article 2(4) of the UN Charter.²⁰¹ Non-intervention extended the SR.31, at 11 (Yugoslavia: non-intervention is a ‘natural corollary of Article 2(4)’ of the UN Charter); UNGA, ‘Special Committee on Principles of International Law Concerning Friendly Relations and Cooperation Among States, First Session, Summary Records of the Thirtieth Meeting’, at 5–6 (Mexico: Article 2(4) is among the provisions of the Charter that provided ‘a solid and irrefutable basis’ for non-intervention).
¹⁹⁸ Interpretation of the Agreement of 25 March 1951 Between the WHO and Egypt (Advisory Opinion) [20 December 1980] ICJ Rep. 73, at para. 10.
¹⁹⁹ J. Crawford, Chance, Order, Change: The Course of International Law, General Course on Public International Law (Brill Nijhoff 2014), at 56.
²⁰⁰ G. Abi-Saab, ‘Whither the International Community?’ (1998) 9 European Journal of International Law 248–265, at 254.
²⁰¹ ‘Political independence’ refers to ‘the autonomy in the affairs of the State with respect to its institutions, freedom of political decisions, policy making, and in matters pertaining to its domestic and foreign affairs’. See S. Blay, ‘Territorial Integrity and Political Independence’ in R. It protects the physical space within which a State exercises political independence against outside intrusion or trespass. See C. Marxsen, ‘Territorial Integrity in International</https:> HELAL protection afforded to the territorial integrity and political independence of States against the threat or use of force to all other instruments of statecraft that could be employed to achieve the same objectives,²⁰² especially that such non-forcible intervention often has the potential to achieve greater harm to States than the threat or use of force.²⁰³ To be clear, the unified threshold of coercion proposed here should not be read as suggesting that non-intervention is coterminous with the prohibition on the threat or use of force. Far from it. Although both rules share the same policy purposes, the prohibition on intervention is broader than the prohibition on the threat or use of force. Non-intervention applies to any policy or practice, whether forcible and non-forcible, that impinges on the political independence or territorial integrity of States. In a sense, therefore, the prohibition on the threat or use of force should be viewed as a *lex specialis* that applies to a specific genus of intervention (namely, *armed* intervention). This body of *lex specialis* has been subsumed, *in toto*, within the broader *lex generalis* of the prohibition on intervention.
In conclusion, further research and further expressions of State views are needed on the definition and threshold of coercion. This is essential to understanding how the prohibition on intervention applies to and governs non-forcible conduct both in cyberspace and beyond. To this writer, however, the unified threshold of coercion that this article proposes provides a conceptual foundation on which to formulate a workable and conceptually coherent approach to applying the prohibition on intervention.

As Georges Abi-Saab wrote: 'The international legal system is based at present as in the past, on two fundamental principles that determine its structure and functioning, namely, the sovereignty and equality of States [...] The principal legal consequence of this structural or rather structuring principle is to commit each State to a general obligation to respect the sovereignty of others; in other words, not to trespass on the territorial and functional ambits of this sovereignty. The most flagrant manifestation of such trespass is the threat or use of force against the State. But it is not the only one. Other, less blatant, forms exist varying in their degree of visibility and intensity. It is precisely the rest of this continuum, beyond the use of force, which is covered by the principle of non-intervention'. G. Abi-Saab, 'Some Thoughts on the Principle of Non-Intervention' in K. metadata.title: Coercion in Cyberspace – Taking Stock of the Debate
metadata.abstract: This article explores debates among States on the application of the prohibition on intervention in cyberspace. It focuses on coercion as an element of the prohibition on intervention and identifies the different definitions of coercion that States have adopted in national and regional position papers on the application of international law in cyberspace. This article also specifically discusses the views of States on the threshold of coercion, which is the degree of harm or the effects that the conduct of a State must cause (or threaten to cause) to amount to a violation of the prohibition on intervention. This article argues that the definitions and thresholds of coercion that States have adopted in debates on the application of international law in cyberspace should be viewed as proposals for the development of the law in this area, as opposed to restatements of established law. Instead, this article proposes that all forms of intervention should be governed by a ‘unified threshold of coercion’ that applies to both forcible and non-forcible intervention.
